headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Melinda, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Paper Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Melinda, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Paper Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conference over to Vice President, Investor Relations, Jay Royalty. Please go ahead.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Melinda, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us International Paper's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Our key speakers this morning are Mark Sutton, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Carol Ro
componenttext:
Thanks, Melinda, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us International Paper's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. 
Our key speakers this morning are Mark Sutton, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Carol Roberts, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are outlined on Slide 2 of our presentation. We will also present certain non-U.S. GAAP financial information. A reconciliation of those figures to U.S. GAAP financial measures are available on our website. Our website also contains copies of the fourth quarter and 2015 earnings press release and today's presentation slides. 
Lastly, relative to the Ilim JV, Slide 4 provides context around the joint venture's financial information and statistical measures.  With that, I'll turn the call over to Mark Sutton.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining International Paper's fourth quarter and full year call. I want to quickly go over the format we're going to use this morning. I will review the full year 2015 results first, and then I'll tur
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay, and good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining International Paper's fourth quarter and full year call. I want to quickly go over the format we're going to use this morning. I will review the full year 2015 results first, and then I'll turn it over to Carol to discuss our fourth quarter results and the performances of our individual businesses, and then come back and cover the outlook before we open it up for Q&A. 
So I'm going to begin on Slide 5. International Paper finished a very solid year in 2015. We achieved a return on invested capital of 11%, a little above our cost of capital. And this makes it the sixth consecutive year that our actual returns are above our cost of capital. Our free cash flow came in strong as well at $1.8 billion, and our earnings per share of $3.65 was the highest EPS in 20 years. That was largely driven by strong results in our North American Industrial Packaging business and record level of results from our Ilim joint venture in Russia. 
Additionally, we completed the sale of our 55% stake in the Sun JV in China at the beginning of the fourth quarter. We received $25 million in cash, in addition to eliminating approximately $400 million of consolidated debt from our balance sheet. 
We also made another meaningful increase to our dividend by 10% in the fourth quarter. And we enhanced our dividend policy, moving the target payout range to 40% to 50% of free cash flow, up from 30% to 40%. We feel confident in this change because it's based on the pressure test we did and updated, which provides a level of confidence to us that our businesses in different economic times have the ability to produce a very sustainable cash, and hence, the sustainable dividend. 
And finally, we continued our strong track record on share buyback as an additional means of returning cash to shareholders, buying more than 500 million shares in 2015. As of this call, total purchases since the inception of the buyback program in September of 2013 amount to about $2.1 billion. 
Moving to slide 6, and turning to the full year financial results. I'd like to highlight a couple of items on this slide. Year-over-year EPS when adjusted for the noncash FX charge on Ilim's U.S. dollar-denominated debt was up 5.5%. Revenue is down roughly 5% with the most significant factor being FX translation. And overall EBITDA margins continue to be strong at 17.6%. 
On Slide 7, you can see that 2015 continued to trend a strong sustainable free cash flow, which has averaged $1.3 billion over the last several years. As we look into 2016 and beyond, we remain confident that IP has a portfolio that can continue to generate strong free cash flow results. We believe free cash flow generation and ROIC above the cost of capital are 2 key drivers of shareholder value. So we think we're on the right track. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Carol to discuss the specifics of the fourth quarter.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I'm on Slide 8. As Mark said earlier, EPS of $3.65 per share is the highest level of 20 years and compares favorably to $3 per share in 2014. Looking at the details, price and mix declines across the North America
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I'm on Slide 8. As Mark said earlier, EPS of $3.65 per share is the highest level of 20 years and compares favorably to $3 per share in 2014. Looking at the details, price and mix declines across the North American businesses were essentially offset by favorable input cost. Volume was generally flat across most businesses, with the exception of reduced export volume from the North American Containerboard business. Operations largely performed in line with expectations with cost-reduction initiatives offsetting the majority of inflation for the year. Slightly higher taxes were more than offset by lower interest expense and lower share count. And the Ilim JV posted significantly higher results due to improved operation, increased margins and a less negative FX impact on the JV's U.S. dollar-denominated debt. 
Turning to the fourth quarter, free cash flow was strong at $501 million. Industrial Packaging delivered another solid quarter based on steady daily box demand. Additional downtime was taken to balance our supply with our demand as overall demand was impacted by 3 fewer shipping days as compared to the third quarter. Domestic prices were generally stable across our North American businesses. And volumes were seasonally higher, along with increased prices in Brazil, Russia and Europe, primarily in our paper business. And finally, the Ilim JV turned in another strong quarter of results, but was unfavorably impacted by a $0.05 noncash FX charge on the JV U.S. dollar-denominated debt. 
Moving to the quarter-over-quarter bridge. As I mentioned, prices were generally stable across the businesses. Volume was unfavorably impacted by 3 less shipping days in the fourth quarter for the North American box business, and we did have reduced export volume. This was partially offset by stronger volume in Europe and Brazil. Operations were negatively impacted by weather and flooding on the East Coast and were further impacted by higher operating cost in the quarter, including costs associated with the increased levels of maintenance and downtime taken to balance our supply with our demand. Quarterly earnings benefited from a favorable input costs and a lower noncash FX charge at the Ilim JV. 
Turning to the businesses and beginning with Industrial Packaging on Slide 11. Volume, as I said, was impacted by 3 fewer shipping days in our U.S. box business, and we did have lower export shipments. The daily shipment rates for boxes was up almost 4% over the third quarter and was flat year-over-year against the strong comp for IP. Operational costs were higher significantly impacted by 322,000 tons of downtime. 230,000 tons of which were taken to balance our supply with our demand. And operating cost were also slightly higher in our Brazil and European packaging businesses. 
Turning to Slide 12, I want to provide some color on the North American box business and what we're experiencing in our shipment in the key segments we serve. As you can see, we experienced a 2% increase in year-over-year shipments on a per day basis from the fourth quarter of '13 to the fourth quarter of '14. And then in the fourth quarter of this year, or last year, we essentially held that increased level of demand. I would say, the market has even been a bit stronger than what we have experienced. 
From a key segment standpoint, we continue to be encouraged by some of the trends we're seeing. We continue to see substantial growth in the e-commerce and distribution segment, in which we are a strong player. Another important trend is in the agricultural segment, which is benefiting from shifting consumer trends to more healthy food. And new product offerings in the beverage segment are also driving some pockets of new growth. Overall, we see a healthy box market that will continue to benefit from evolving consumer trends. 
Moving to Consumer Packaging. The business experienced the less favorable mix and lower volume due to 3 less shipping days. The fourth quarter was a higher operating cost quarter. And the North American business experienced some transition costs associated with the shutdown of the coated paperboard machine at Riegelwood related to preparations for the conversion project. Average expenses were higher as expected, and input cost were favorable. Finally, earnings improved due to the sale of our share of the Sun JV. 
Turning to Slide 14 and the Paper business. IP experienced price increases in Brazil, Europe and Russia as well as a seasonally favorable mix improvement in Brazil that was partially offset by pulp price pressure in the quarter. Volume was higher primarily due to seasonal strength in Brazil and Europe. Operations were negatively impacted in North America due to extreme weather and flooding on the East Coast. Some effects which will linger into the first quarter. Operating cost were seasonally higher as well. The negative FX swing here is simply the nonrepeat of the favorable Brazilian FX impact that we experienced in the third quarter. 
Turning to Slide 15. I want to provide an update on the Riegelwood Mill conversion project. As we announced last year, we are converting the mill to 100% pulp with the capability to run an additional 400,000 tons of soft wood and/or fluff pulp. This will bring our total North American system to a capacity of 1.7 million tons, of which 1.5 million can produce fluff pulp. The project is well underway, having shut down the first coated paperboard machine, PM18, which is the one that's actually being converted, and we did that in December. And we shutdown the second machine, PM15, in January. We will bring the converted machine back online in May, which means half the mill will be down for roughly half the year. Once online, we expect to fully ramp up on softwood pulp and qualified PM 18 on fluff pulp by the end of the year. This will ensure we have adequate capacity for our key fluff customers as their demanded grows. For the balance of the year, we expect to run and sell mostly market softwood pulp. We will incur costs associated with the conversion and the ramp up. In total, we expect the conversion impact in 2016 to impact earnings by roughly $75 million to $80 million, with about $50 million impacting our first quarter earnings. And that's when the bulk of the conversion work will be done and much of the mill will be down actually also for the annual outage. And then, there will be some ramp up cost beyond that, that will spread into the second and third quarters. 
Now turning to Ilim. The JV concluded a strong year of operational and financial results as the focus shifted to optimizing and leveraging the completed investments and their very advantage export position. The JV achieved record operational EBITDA results of $724 million in 2015 and IP's corresponding equity earnings were $131 million. During the quarter, the JV refinanced the portion of their U.S. dollar debt to rubles. 
Relative to the first quarter outlook, the JV expect to continue its strong operational and cost performance against higher inflation, lower pulp prices and the expected weaker seasonality. 
Before I turn to the outlook for the first quarter, I want to just give a quick update on IP's balance sheet. As of December 31, 2015, our balance sheet debt declined slightly to $9.3 billion. The pension GAAP declined by $300 million. In 2015, we made a $750 million voluntary contribution to the pension in the second quarter. Additionally, we had a bond issue and tender offer which further reduced our debt powers in 2018 and 2021 at lower interest rates. And I'd also remind you that we increased our dividend, as Mark said, 10% to $1.76 and brought back a little more than 500 million of stock in 2015. And currently, we're maintaining a cash balance of about $1 billion. 
So moving to the first quarter outlook on Slide 18. Earnings associated with volume will be lower for the following reasons: Number one, channel mix in our North American Industrial Packaging business will be -- impact earnings by $25 million as box volume will be seasonally weaker and export volume will be stronger. Secondly, our North American Consumer Packaging business will be impacted by roughly $5 million due to the exit of the Bristol's -- of the Carolina volume. And third, seasonally lower volume in Brazil will impact earnings by roughly $25 million. 
Pricing is expected to be lower for the North American pulp and paper businesses. These are expected to impact earnings by roughly $20 million. Price for our North American Industrial Packaging will be impacted by continued lower export pricing, along with the recent PBW index change. All in, this is expected to impact earnings by $20 million. Prices are expected to improve in both European, Russia and Brazil papers as recent price increase are implemented. These will be somewhat offset by inflationary cost pressures in those regions. 
Operations are expected to be generally at the same level as the fourth quarter. Operational cost are expected to improve modestly in North American Industrial Packaging. Maintenance outage expense will increase collectively by $56 million as shown on the slide, inclusive of the higher outage cost associated with the Riegelwood conversion, as I mentioned earlier. 
And as always, we provide an outlook for Ilim assuming stable FX coming our of the quarter, so the first quarter outlook assumes a nonrepeat of the $0.05 charge we incurred in the fourth quarter. 
So with that, let me turn it over to Mark.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Carol. Before I return to 2016, I just like to reiterate that I feel really good about our results in 2015. I'm on Slide 19 right now. The year didn't play out the way we envisioned coming into it, but given hwo things unfolded across the globe, I
componenttext:
Thanks, Carol. Before I return to 2016, I just like to reiterate that I feel really good about our results in 2015. I'm on Slide 19 right now. The year didn't play out the way we envisioned coming into it, but given hwo things unfolded across the globe, I think we played our hand pretty well and had a number of significant accomplishments in 2015. I'm really proud of the way our teams stepped up and dealt with the environment that we were really dealing with, not the one we thought we were going to be dealing with. 
Turning now to 2016. Sitting here today, it's really difficult to predict where things might go from a global macro standpoint. We feel good about how we're positioned to deal with whatever the market brings and the agility that we have in IP to adjust as needed. As you can see from the chart, CapEx for 2016 is $1.3 billion. This will ensure we get the most important things done, and it reinforces our commitment to remain highly focused on maximizing free cash flow. As we highlighted earlier on this call, IP has delivered consistently strong results and return on invested capital and free cash flow for the last several years, and I have every confidence we'll do so again in 2016. 
Turning to Slide 20. Beyond keeping our employees safe and being good stewards of the environment and being good citizens in the communities in which we operate, we have a robustness of focus items for 2016. At the top of that list is a very good reason is continuing to improve our North American Industrial Packaging system. We have a great foundation to build upon, but we certainly have many opportunities to optimize further across all aspects of the business. The Riegelwood conversion has begun with the objective of having the mill up and running in May and fully ramped up by the fourth quarter. Our teams are keenly focused on making this happen safely and on time and getting the new machine qualified in quick order to supply fluff pulp. Additionally, we are executing our plan to grow our cup business at our recently expanded in Ohio cup facility. This will enable us to take care of our key customers' growing needs in this important segment as consumers drive to shift -- continue to drive the shift from foam to fiber-based packaging. 
Another focus item for us in 2016 is to optimize our North American paper portfolio by aligning with the most attractive customers and the opportunities to deliver a strong value proposition to those customers. We're also working towards the sale of our Asia box business as we announced last October. And the Ilim JV had a strong year in 2015, and we expect another strong performance in 2016. 
And finally, we remain focused on maximizing free cash flow generation and deploying that capital in a way that creates additional value for our shareholders. All of these positions International Paper to have another successful year in 2016. 
And as I wrap up in closing, before we go to Q&A, I go back to the investment thesis for International Paper. We've built a portfolio with strong competitive positions in key markets where IP has a right to win. I like our portfolio, and we'll continue to look for opportunities to improve the company as we go forward. Our strategy has enabled us to achieve and increase the spread of our return on invested capital above our cost of capital, and we've been doing this for the last 6 years. In addition to that, we've proven that we can generate strong sustainable free cash flow, year in and year out, and we've been doing that for several years now. We remain highly focused on the capital allocation strategy as based on very simple principles of creating value, rewarding our shareholders and making International Paper better. 
And with that, I'd like to turn it back over to the operator and open the floor for questions.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Carol. I'm going to start and then I'm going to turn it over to Tim. So we've got 2 things happening. One is Riegelwood is now going to be classified in the paper business because it's North American paper and pulp. So that's why you don't s
componenttext: Mark, this is Carol. I'm going to start and then I'm going to turn it over to Tim. So we've got 2 things happening. One is Riegelwood is now going to be classified in the paper business because it's North American paper and pulp. So that's why you don't see the impact in consumer. And so the increase you see on the paper side in the appendix is around Riegelwood. And I'm going to let Tim comment on the Industrial Packaging piece.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, most of it is just additional -- is the nature of the projects that we have in the mills from year-to-year we get variation and depending on what comes up in the cycle for maintenance in 1 year can be different from the next. And so in 5 of our larg
componenttext: Mark, most of it is just additional -- is the nature of the projects that we have in the mills from year-to-year we get variation and depending on what comes up in the cycle for maintenance in 1 year can be different from the next. And so in 5 of our larger mills, we have more expenses items to deal with in 2016 than we did in 2015.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And if I could real quickly. Could you update us on how business in Industrial Packaging has been looking through January? And also a little bit more color on the e-commerce side of things. What percentage of your Industrial Packaging is e-commerce
componenttext: Great. And if I could real quickly. Could you update us on how business in Industrial Packaging has been looking through January? And also a little bit more color on the e-commerce side of things. What percentage of your Industrial Packaging is e-commerce now? And what type of growth have you been seeing?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the growth is good. It's a relatively small segment in terms of the total business, but it's a rapidly growing segment. So we had a strong fourth quarter, especially in December, around e-commerce. That continued into the first part of January. As y
componenttext: Well, the growth is good. It's a relatively small segment in terms of the total business, but it's a rapidly growing segment. So we had a strong fourth quarter, especially in December, around e-commerce. That continued into the first part of January. As you know, if you order something online, you get a box when you receive it, and then if you have to return it, you use another box to send it back and swap it out. So it carried over a little bit into January. Our January was, I'd say more, or less the way we expected it. We did have a little bit of impact from weather with the snowstorms that moved through. And if you remember, January last year was a bit of an anomalous month with January 2 the way it fell right before a weekend, and was it a work day, wasn't it a work day. So it's a pretty strong comp with some confused workdays for January. But as we look through all of that, January was expected. And first quarter looks to be more or less as we expect. We're expecting that we'll be flat on an absolute basis in the first quarter, but we do model our -- the market demand growth, what we're anticipating. And things could change, but the model right now says that it could be as much as 1% in the first quarter.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on the pension situation. I know you all made a big payment last year and you made some headway, at least as of the year end, with the net pension balance. But how should we think about what the contributions may or may not be, let's say
componenttext: First question is on the pension situation. I know you all made a big payment last year and you made some headway, at least as of the year end, with the net pension balance. But how should we think about what the contributions may or may not be, let's say, in the next 3 years? If you could give us a view on that.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Chip. This is Carol. So yes, the pension gap was reduced by 300. We did make the contribution. Of course, we have other moving parts, which is the rate change was helpful. There were some actuarial changes on some demographics that was unhelpful. An
componenttext: Sure, Chip. This is Carol. So yes, the pension gap was reduced by 300. We did make the contribution. Of course, we have other moving parts, which is the rate change was helpful. There were some actuarial changes on some demographics that was unhelpful. And as we all know, asset performance the way we're invested was not totally a particularly stellar year last year. So all in, we saw the benefit of 300. As it relates to required contributions, we have no required contribution for '16 or '17. And then when you get out to '18, it's going to be all around our asset performance over the next 2 years, and then where interest rates goes, depending on where policy changes. So that would be how to think about it.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so at this point, is there plans to make any kind of voluntary payments this year or next year?
componenttext: And so at this point, is there plans to make any kind of voluntary payments this year or next year?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point, I wouldn't speculate on that. Things could always change depending upon what may happen. But at this point, I would say that we don't anticipate any contribution.
componenttext: At this point, I wouldn't speculate on that. Things could always change depending upon what may happen. But at this point, I would say that we don't anticipate any contribution.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: And then as we look at CapEx, I might be mistaken, but I think you've kind of come down twice. I do know that you announced containerboard system initiative in the back in July and we kind of added that, and then I think in October, I believe you sort of gave us a view of about $1.4 billion. Now it's down to $1.3 billion. And my question is, what should we expect it to be in sort of an ongoing basis, '17, '18? In other words, would the containerboard initiative, I would think, unless there's something similar to back that up -- beyond that, you could be even see maybe a slip further in the future.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chip, this is Mark. I think you've said it correctly. When we announced these containerboard projects, we didn't say we were raising capital. I think the assumption in the market was that we were. So I don't deal quit with coming down twice. We said $1.4
componenttext: Chip, this is Mark. I think you've said it correctly. When we announced these containerboard projects, we didn't say we were raising capital. I think the assumption in the market was that we were. So I don't deal quit with coming down twice. We said $1.4 billion was probably the preliminary scope we had in the fourth quarter. We were fine that and looking at the actual year and the projects. And our capital allocation policy and so we come in at $1.3 billion. And I think we've said before with the asset-based we have and the culture we have in our company to operate safe environmentally sound and reliable operations, we tend to have a base load in that $1 billion range. And then above that, it's to hopefully improve the company with cost reduction, strategic investments, for example, like our cup project at word. And that's the flexibility, and then over time, against the backdrop of our capital allocation principles.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last question. You certainly gave a nice boost of the dividend late last year. How do you view, I guess, buybacks versus other possible uses beyond the dividend? Of course, in light of where the stock price might be, especially given the de
componenttext: Okay. And then last question. You certainly gave a nice boost of the dividend late last year. How do you view, I guess, buybacks versus other possible uses beyond the dividend? Of course, in light of where the stock price might be, especially given the decline we've seen in the last 6 months.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question. I think we use the word balanced use of cash and then finding the right ways to return cash to investors. We like what we've done with the dividend in that 40% to 50% target area we plan on maintaining. And the share buybacks
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. I think we use the word balanced use of cash and then finding the right ways to return cash to investors. We like what we've done with the dividend in that 40% to 50% target area we plan on maintaining. And the share buybacks will continue to be opportunistic. And hopefully, we do a really good job of buying as much as we can at the right value, below the intrinsic value of the company. And we'll continue to do that. We still got $900 million left on the authorization. So we've got more that you can do, and we plan on doing it.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttextpreview: So this is Carol. Again, what I would say is, as we all now, we're living in a very uncertain outlook for the world. And so it's very difficult to pin it down on any one metric. But I think what you can see is the things we feel very confident about is un
componenttext: So this is Carol. Again, what I would say is, as we all now, we're living in a very uncertain outlook for the world. And so it's very difficult to pin it down on any one metric. But I think what you can see is the things we feel very confident about is underlying businesses, their strength, the ability to sustain the cash flow. And that's why we raised the dividend. So I feel very good about cash flow. We'll make adjustments as we go. And we have not, in the past, provided guidance, and we're not intending to do that in the future.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Amick. As we look at the board business, clearly, Q4 is a seasonally slower time, and we certainly saw that. But what we're seeing as we move into this year is backlogs and orders are responding as kind of what we expect to see. We're startin
componenttext: This is Mike Amick. As we look at the board business, clearly, Q4 is a seasonally slower time, and we certainly saw that. But what we're seeing as we move into this year is backlogs and orders are responding as kind of what we expect to see. We're starting to see some of that pick up a little bit, which is typical for this time of the year. We have a good solid business and good customers and really targeted segments around good service. On the import side, what we are seeing, some imports coming in, our experience, primarily if you look at cost in North America, that's in Latin America where we see that in some of the commodity segments.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

I know there are certain limitations you can comment on pricing, but any color would be helpful because, obviously, investors are a little nervous that we're competing [indiscernible] it's not won and done. Any color will be great. Thanks.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Tim. Well, I can't comment on the industry, I'll comment on what we're doing and what we see. We're a big player in the export markets. Export markets have been volatile as we went through the second half of last year, but it's really been a volatili
componenttext: It's Tim. Well, I can't comment on the industry, I'll comment on what we're doing and what we see. We're a big player in the export markets. Export markets have been volatile as we went through the second half of last year, but it's really been a volatility around price and margin, not a volatility around demand. There are some pockets of where demand is a little bit weaker, namely Turkey, which where we're very large supplier to that market. And some of the Mid East conflict has spilled over. But on balance, demand has held up fairly well. And we continue to see that in the first quarter. January was right as we expected, and February looks to be pretty solid from an advanced standpoint. In the box business, as I said a minute to go, we're expecting roughly a flat absolute tonnage first quarter versus last year. And our model, our demand model that we use says that the market could grow upwards of a percent in the first quarter. We've got some segment mixed uses that we've been working through. We've been trailing markets we did up for all of 2015. So we'll probably underperform in the first quarter to what we think the market is going to grow. But overall, it's about like what we expected.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful just because comps are pretty tough in the first quarter, if I remember correctly last year.
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful just because comps are pretty tough in the first quarter, if I remember correctly last year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, they are.  It's the toughest quarter of the year.
componenttext: Yes, they are.  It's the toughest quarter of the year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson with KeyBanc.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: One -- and perhaps for you. Just on the sequential decline of box prices in North American in the fourth quarter, what drove that exactly? And is it fair to assume that, that had nothing to do with anything that pulp and paper did in recent months?
componenttext: One -- and perhaps for you. Just on the sequential decline of box prices in North American in the fourth quarter, what drove that exactly? And is it fair to assume that, that had nothing to do with anything that pulp and paper did in recent months?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct. It did not. And a big portion of that is mix. So what you see flowing through to the EBIT impact is about $1 or maybe slightly more than $1, and price that came through as we went through contract negotiations with customers during th
componenttext: Yes, that's correct. It did not. And a big portion of that is mix. So what you see flowing through to the EBIT impact is about $1 or maybe slightly more than $1, and price that came through as we went through contract negotiations with customers during the course of the year. The rest of it was mix, which means, it hits price but it doesn't necessarily hit margins. So boxes sell for different prices. As your customer mix and your segment mix changes, they can move price, but it doesn't change margin. So that's what it was. Just a little bit of contract renegotiations that were flowing through.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is that a seasonal issue, Tim? Or not necessarily? Which we see it every fourth quarter?
componenttext: And is that a seasonal issue, Tim? Or not necessarily? Which we see it every fourth quarter?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily. I mean, we can, in any given year, given the size of the business, we can renegotiate anywhere from 1 million to 2 million tons of business with large customers just because of how the contract period falls. So it just depends on what's h
componenttext: Not necessarily. I mean, we can, in any given year, given the size of the business, we can renegotiate anywhere from 1 million to 2 million tons of business with large customers just because of how the contract period falls. So it just depends on what's happening in the quarter and what gets agreed to and finalized in the quarter.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carol, one for you, just on taxes. Can you talk about what your cash taxes were in 2015 versus your book taxes? Obviously, there's been a substantial gap between the 2 over the past several years. I'm just wondering what that was in '15 or what your expec
componenttext: Carol, one for you, just on taxes. Can you talk about what your cash taxes were in 2015 versus your book taxes? Obviously, there's been a substantial gap between the 2 over the past several years. I'm just wondering what that was in '15 or what your expectations are in '16 and beyond for that matter?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There was a gap between book and actual again in '15, and you'll see that when the tail come out very shortly. And that was driven, of course, by the voluntary contribution of pension, which creates a nice tax deduction. Over time, as we've told ever
componenttext: Yes. There was a gap between book and actual again in '15, and you'll see that when the tail come out very shortly. And that was driven, of course, by the voluntary contribution of pension, which creates a nice tax deduction. Over time, as we've told everybody, we do anticipate that our cash taxes will go up and start to approach the statutory rate, but there's still some time before that actually comes totally to fruition.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dr. Mark Wilde with BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dr. Mark Wilde with BMO Capital Markets.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, I wondered if you could just talk about that 230,000 tons of containerboard downtime in the fourth quarter. How much of that is seasonal or transitional? Or does it maybe suggest that you need to think about your -- rethink your footprint?
componenttext: Tim, I wondered if you could just talk about that 230,000 tons of containerboard downtime in the fourth quarter. How much of that is seasonal or transitional? Or does it maybe suggest that you need to think about your -- rethink your footprint?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think it's a question of footprint. There's a number of factors, Mark, that played into it. First of all, we did have more of a shortfall in our export channel in the fourth quarter than we anticipated. Now as I said a moment ago, it has bounc
componenttext: No, I don't think it's a question of footprint. There's a number of factors, Mark, that played into it. First of all, we did have more of a shortfall in our export channel in the fourth quarter than we anticipated. Now as I said a moment ago, it has bounced back in the first quarter. So that was one element: Fewer days. But the other thing that's going on, we've got a much better in stock position of roll stock in our box plants than we've traditionally had over the past 2 or 3 years. So that help us well. And then probably the last one, we did see an improved efficiency in our supply chain network. There were more rail cars available, there were more trucks available. It could be that the just point in time, and it doesn't continue as a trend, but we were reacting to just the velocity, which inventory was flowing through the system as well. So it's just -- you look at a macro number for what we do around downtime, but that's not how we manage it. We're managing thousands of SKUs, 200 locations and trying to get the right product in the right place at the right time. And so that all factors in to the amount of downtime we take or don't take.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then if I could kind of follow on with you, Tim, on packaging. The Brazilian business is significantly underperforming. Can you kind of help us understand the issues there? And then what you think the time line looks like to getting that busines
componenttext: Okay. And then if I could kind of follow on with you, Tim, on packaging. The Brazilian business is significantly underperforming. Can you kind of help us understand the issues there? And then what you think the time line looks like to getting that business at least close to the peers?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mark Sutton. I'll take the Brazil question and relieve Tim of that because he's got that as part of our Brazil team. The challenges with the business is, obviously, Brazil is in a pretty significant recession. The business we have is pretty much a
componenttext: This is Mark Sutton. I'll take the Brazil question and relieve Tim of that because he's got that as part of our Brazil team. The challenges with the business is, obviously, Brazil is in a pretty significant recession. The business we have is pretty much all domestic business. It doesn't have a large export, it doesn't have an export position which is the model that's more typical, which is exporting craft liner. We use everything we make. And so you got demand down pretty much tracking with negative GDP. And what's been a challenge, and we're making progress is, the ability to get pricing to at a minimum offset inflation. So we raised containerboard prices in the fourth quarter, those are implemented. And we're in the process of raising box prices. But being 100% depending on the Brazilian economy, which, I think, for the long term is not a bad thing. For the last couple of years and for this year and maybe even next year, it's a bit of a challenge. So we're just trying to stabilize our business, make sure we have the right customers. We've taken out a lot of cost, but we obviously have to get some inflation recovery, and that's what we're working on.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally, I wondered if you could just talk a little bit about the impact of the duties in the North American white paper market? And whether you -- how you read impact as we roll into 2016?
componenttext: Okay. And then finally, I wondered if you could just talk a little bit about the impact of the duties in the North American white paper market? And whether you -- how you read impact as we roll into 2016?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Amick. Good question. As you know, there was a ruling here a couple of weeks ago with respect to kind of finalizing the duties, and there was some movement there. There's ITC will basically have their hearing on the second week of February, a
componenttext: This is Mike Amick. Good question. As you know, there was a ruling here a couple of weeks ago with respect to kind of finalizing the duties, and there was some movement there. There's ITC will basically have their hearing on the second week of February, and then we'll kind of know the outcome relative to entry. The best way to answer that right now is to kind of look at what we kind of expect to see as a run rate and how this is impacted imports, say, versus 2014. And we're somewhere in the range of say 300,000 to 400,000 tons of imports that have kind of come out of the market with respect to the duties. But we'll wait and see how the ITC rules in February.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Mike, is there any sense of sort of where inventory stands because there's been a lot talk that there was a lot of inventory that got built in the country by some of the offshore producers?
componenttext: And Mike, is there any sense of sort of where inventory stands because there's been a lot talk that there was a lot of inventory that got built in the country by some of the offshore producers?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I mean, the inventories that we see right now, what we track industry numbers that you see as well. We see those as being kind of in the normal range. We saw some slight pickup in the fourth quarter, but nothing that we would characterize as being u
componenttext: Mark, I mean, the inventories that we see right now, what we track industry numbers that you see as well. We see those as being kind of in the normal range. We saw some slight pickup in the fourth quarter, but nothing that we would characterize as being unusually abnormal.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Mark Connelly with CLSA.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Mark Connelly with CLSA.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 questions. IP and others have said that you need more inventory to deal with the logistics issues that we're having. But as we look at overall inventories, do you think that there's a chance that the industry maybe overshooting in aggregate? I'm just tr
componenttext: 2 questions. IP and others have said that you need more inventory to deal with the logistics issues that we're having. But as we look at overall inventories, do you think that there's a chance that the industry maybe overshooting in aggregate? I'm just trying to recalibrate. I look at 2.5 million tons, which is a lot more than we've seen in the past, and especially with all the supply work, maybe that's a little high.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Tim. I can only comment on what we do and how we run our system. We did feel, as we went through last year, that we needed more because of some of the difficulties we were facing just in terms of this railcar and truck availability. As I mentioned a
componenttext: It's Tim. I can only comment on what we do and how we run our system. We did feel, as we went through last year, that we needed more because of some of the difficulties we were facing just in terms of this railcar and truck availability. As I mentioned a minute ago, that changed in December. I don't know that, that's a trend, I don't think it is necessarily because nothing stands still, people react. But we had better velocity through the system in the fourth quarter. It continued into the first part of January, and we'll see how it plays out over the balance of the year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just one other question. You've now taken several substantial asset write-downs in the last couple of quarters. I'm wondering if that's part of a concerted effort on your part to get these assets on the books at the right numbers? Or if you thin
componenttext: Okay. And just one other question. You've now taken several substantial asset write-downs in the last couple of quarters. I'm wondering if that's part of a concerted effort on your part to get these assets on the books at the right numbers? Or if you think that there are more of these coming?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Carol. It's just part of the normal process of running the company properly. We do goodwill impairment testing with our strategic plans every year in the fourth quarter. As we did that testing, clearly, we had the issue with the results. So
componenttext: Mark, this is Carol. It's just part of the normal process of running the company properly. We do goodwill impairment testing with our strategic plans every year in the fourth quarter. As we did that testing, clearly, we had the issue with the results. So we moved that goodwill off. So that's just part of normal running of the company.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Chris Manuel with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Chris Manuel with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to kind of come back to -- can you give -- Tim, you gave some color on what you thought industry and your sales might look like in 1Q, and I kind of wanted to spend a minute and talk a little bit about of all of '16. In particular, we have an ext
componenttext: I wanted to kind of come back to -- can you give -- Tim, you gave some color on what you thought industry and your sales might look like in 1Q, and I kind of wanted to spend a minute and talk a little bit about of all of '16. In particular, we have an extra day this year, fewer elements play a little bit of the normal stuff population growth, increasing e-commerce, et cetera. How do you feel about full year '16? Could we see another 1 point, 1.5 points, 2 points of corrugated consumption box growth in full year '16, part 1. And then part 2, IP has lagged a little bit the industry. And can you maybe give us a little color on what you were talking about with some of the mix and issues and things there? And could that begin to kind of revert back to averages?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, just on the last part, we're making choices. We're in segments that we've been in for a long time. There's customers in those segments shift. Some years, segments perform better than other years, and so it will ebb and flow. But we're trying to make
componenttext: Well, just on the last part, we're making choices. We're in segments that we've been in for a long time. There's customers in those segments shift. Some years, segments perform better than other years, and so it will ebb and flow. But we're trying to make commercial decisions, choices that we think the same margins and build value over time. On your question on growth for the year. Yes, I do think that it could be in that 1 point to 1.5 point range. That's what our model says. Having said that, box consumption is not totally disconnected from the economy. So it will depend on economic performance as we go through the year. But right now, what we see in terms of how the economy is performing, there's no reason to believe that itw you'd be less than that 1% to 1.5% that we saw last year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then Mark, a quick question on kind of the portfolio as you sit today. Look, I mean prices, obviously, equity markets have been hit pretty hard, yourselves included. But as you look out at a cash-on-cash return and opportunities,
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then Mark, a quick question on kind of the portfolio as you sit today. Look, I mean prices, obviously, equity markets have been hit pretty hard, yourselves included. But as you look out at a cash-on-cash return and opportunities, how you think about M&A, done a lot of work on the portfolio, kind of getting out of some parts pieces globally that you wanted to. From where you sit today, what's the temperature or the appetite to look at opportunity to add to the portfolio?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, that's a good question. I mean, I think it's a constant process of looking at ways to create more value for our shareholders and then make the company better and a longer term value creator. So we've got a lot parts of our portfolio, or as I descri
componenttext: Chris, that's a good question. I mean, I think it's a constant process of looking at ways to create more value for our shareholders and then make the company better and a longer term value creator. So we've got a lot parts of our portfolio, or as I described, really excellent positions, great fiber baskets, super customer list, wonderful operations, assets and people. But there's other areas where we're still working and we'll continue to do that to improve the company. But our focus area is really creating value and growing the value of the company. And if M&A can play a role as we've said before, then it will be on the table. But it'll be targeted in our areas of creating value, advantage positions and serving, growing solid end markets. Now just about growth rates of unit volume or anything, but really going after where we can find the profit pulls that we can be a competitive right-wing kind of company.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Gatner with Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Gatner with Barclays.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually John Dominion sitting in for Scott. Just one question or a couple of questions on a couple of segments. Within corrugated packaging, the global cost driver appears to be flattening out due to FX with lower cost producing Brazil and Russia
componenttext: This is actually John Dominion sitting in for Scott. Just one question or a couple of questions on a couple of segments. Within corrugated packaging, the global cost driver appears to be flattening out due to FX with lower cost producing Brazil and Russia. How is this affecting the global trade flows and the ability for North American producers to export?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, again, I can only speak to how we're looking at it. Yes, they've gotten more cost competitive on currency. And we do see them in all of the markets that we operate in. And so they're there. We're competing against them. It may cost us some margin to
componenttext: Well, again, I can only speak to how we're looking at it. Yes, they've gotten more cost competitive on currency. And we do see them in all of the markets that we operate in. And so they're there. We're competing against them. It may cost us some margin to do that, but it's also not an unlimited amount of capacity that they have in the moment to penetrate the markets that we operate in.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in the Printing Papers segment. You have any impact from the dumping duties yet? And any firming up in the demand or pricing post duties?
componenttext: Okay. And then in the Printing Papers segment. You have any impact from the dumping duties yet? And any firming up in the demand or pricing post duties?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike Amick. As discussed a little bit earlier, there has been some pullback in imports that we've experienced, say, over the last 18 months or so. We think that, that's -- we may see a little bit more of that, it's primarily probably pretty well l
componenttext: This is Mike Amick. As discussed a little bit earlier, there has been some pullback in imports that we've experienced, say, over the last 18 months or so. We think that, that's -- we may see a little bit more of that, it's primarily probably pretty well leveled out, and we'll see how that plays out in '16.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. And then finally, with OCC forecast that were down about 15%, 20% in 2015 and some forecast showing increased into 2016. What do you think could be for the year? Or do you have any further color on that?
componenttext: Okay, thank you. And then finally, with OCC forecast that were down about 15%, 20% in 2015 and some forecast showing increased into 2016. What do you think could be for the year? Or do you have any further color on that?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On OCC, no. I mean, commodity market, global markets, a lot of puts and takes. Very hard to forecast.
componenttext: On OCC, no. I mean, commodity market, global markets, a lot of puts and takes. Very hard to forecast.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Mark. In addition to Tim's comment, one of the things that we've seen in the OCC is there's just a practical issue with the cost curve is that when you get in the area where prices are now, you get to a point where collecting the final margi
componenttext: John, this is Mark. In addition to Tim's comment, one of the things that we've seen in the OCC is there's just a practical issue with the cost curve is that when you get in the area where prices are now, you get to a point where collecting the final marginal tons becomes uneconomic. So what ends up happening is there's some kind of self-regulating supply disruption that occurs. And so there's not a lot of inventory in the system normally, so that's why it's kind of springs around. But we think people are collecting more, which, but we do think that there's still a practical issue of what  it costs to collect that highest cost marginal ton, which is probably coat side and the kind of things that municipalities are doing, and then people just stop doing it.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of George Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess first question I had, Mark. I want to piggyback a little bit on one of the earlier questions. You've been in the seat now for a while and you've had the opportunity to review the portfolio and the strategy of the company. Recognizing that things a
componenttext: I guess first question I had, Mark. I want to piggyback a little bit on one of the earlier questions. You've been in the seat now for a while and you've had the opportunity to review the portfolio and the strategy of the company. Recognizing that things are going to be fluid going forward, it's not a static market. Have you, in your view, determined which businesses you'd like to be in, which markets you want to continue to grow into? Or would you say you still have some further study to do in terms of the markets and your positioning there?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we pretty much determine where we want to take the company going forward. And it's in the areas that we've been working on. We want to grow our packaging business, and we want to have businesses that, not so much the product focused, but the compe
componenttext: I think we pretty much determine where we want to take the company going forward. And it's in the areas that we've been working on. We want to grow our packaging business, and we want to have businesses that, not so much the product focused, but the competitive advantage. Where we have advantage, assets in advantage, fiber basins making products for growing market, fiber-based products, we win. When we don't have that, we struggle. And so that's really the strategic focus of the company is improving the company. We've got a really great company right now, and it can be improved. But -- we know where we want to go, and we know where we don't want to go. And we'll continue to evolve. And as we have something to talk about when we can, we will.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, is it possible, and maybe the answer is no, but could you put a geographic tilt on what you just said? I mean, do you see more opportunity in the Americas versus rest of the world or however you frame it?
componenttext: Mark, is it possible, and maybe the answer is no, but could you put a geographic tilt on what you just said? I mean, do you see more opportunity in the Americas versus rest of the world or however you frame it?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, if you look at some of our actions over the last year, both things we've done and things we haven't done,  I would say that our view of the Americas is strong. We like our business. Again, where we have advantaged positions in the value add t
componenttext: I would say, if you look at some of our actions over the last year, both things we've done and things we haven't done,  I would say that our view of the Americas is strong. We like our business. Again, where we have advantaged positions in the value add to the renewable natural resources of wood fiber. So the markets we serve, even China, when we talked about exiting our businesses, the market's still important. That is what the Ilim JV is mostly about. And we export 25% of what we make in the U.S. is exported because it's globally competitive, it's containerboard, it's fluff pulp, and it goes to those markets. But we don't necessarily need to have manufacturing assets in every geography in the world.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. 2 questions on rest of the world. Ilim had a really nice performance. Is there a way you could comment to or maybe remind us on what you think the longer term dividend opportunity is in Ilim so that you get maybe more cash flow and more attent
componenttext: Understood. 2 questions on rest of the world. Ilim had a really nice performance. Is there a way you could comment to or maybe remind us on what you think the longer term dividend opportunity is in Ilim so that you get maybe more cash flow and more attention pay for what's a very good asset relative to its carrying value on the book. And then within Brazil, recognizing your differences in terms of your business versus maybe your peers, is it possible to quantify maybe what your level of underperformance is relative to what your opportunity would be -- your opportunity set given your mix of business?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Carol. On the Ilim dividend, a really simple way to think about it is, as the business performs better, clearly, there's cash generation. And, of course, we're respectful of our joint venture partners, and we have a board with very good governance
componenttext: This is Carol. On the Ilim dividend, a really simple way to think about it is, as the business performs better, clearly, there's cash generation. And, of course, we're respectful of our joint venture partners, and we have a board with very good governance of that company of which we're half the board. So what the company does is generally the decision around the dividend is in the time frame of the summertime where they look kind of backwards at the prior year and see the performance and the cash is there. So as you could read into that, you could expect as we evaluate the dividend for 2016, we'll be looking back at the performance of '15, and it was very strong. And then a real simple way is, you could think about it as simply as our equity earnings could, in theory, match the dividend of the company. And then that would be, excluding the FX noncash because that is noncash.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for that, Carol. And on Warsaw?
componenttext: Thanks for that, Carol. And on Warsaw?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: On Warsaw, with the earlier answer to the question, I think, that Mark asked on Brazil. With the current economic environment, it's -- and being totally focused on the Brazilian market, it's hard to guess on the time. But we should be able to get that bus
componenttext: On Warsaw, with the earlier answer to the question, I think, that Mark asked on Brazil. With the current economic environment, it's -- and being totally focused on the Brazilian market, it's hard to guess on the time. But we should be able to get that business under normal market conditions to reasonably good margins. We will probably always have some gap if an expert position of craft liner improve the business at any given moment in time because that's not what we do there. We got that business to begin to develop the packaging presence in Brazil, which we think long-term is a good idea. We did it in a way that's 100% committed to the local market. And it is different than others do it. So it's always going to have a different business model for the foreseeable future. We need a better economy, and we need to be able to get some inflation recovery, which we're working very, very hard on.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Debbie Jones with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Debbie Jones with Deutsche Bank.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

Are we kind of -- is the decline in paper not 3% to 5% on a go-forward basis? Or do you think we've hit a tipping point here? Or maybe it's a little bit less? Could you just comment on that?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: This is Mike Amick. just commenting on the demand environment that we have. Yes, the data that you see out there for 2015, the overall uncoated free sheet market and paper market was done in the 1% range. And -- but if you look at it over the course of the last couple of years, it's basically been down around the 3% to 3.5%, which is kind of what it's been tracking at and what we see happening kind of going forward. In our business, in particular, we've had a very strong year last year, going with some very good clients and very good customers in the right segments. We expect to do well in 2016 as well.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll see how it plays out, Debbie. Our view on our own business is that we'll be flat in the first quarter. We have a view that the market will grow, but we'll see how the economy plays out. We have exposure to certain segments. Protein being one of them
componenttext: We'll see how it plays out, Debbie. Our view on our own business is that we'll be flat in the first quarter. We have a view that the market will grow, but we'll see how the economy plays out. We have exposure to certain segments. Protein being one of them, that underperformed last year given some of the difficulties that the protein customers are facing. And that's still yet to start really recovering. So we'll see how that plays out over '16.

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: We don't see that in the first quarter. We actually expect exports to rebound. January looks like it's coming in about where we expected it. February looks solid. Pricing could drift down. We think it's not a huge drift, but I don't know if markets are beginning to stabilize just yet, but from a volume standpoint, first quarter looks better than fourth.

componenttext: Got it. Thanks. And then can you just provide any thoughts on inflation this year? I know you hit on OCC, but we've seen cost deflation help our quite a bit. Should we expect this to continue through the year? Or do you think fixed cost inflation could be more than offset this year?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Carol. I would say, on the input side, our overall view of input is fairly muted this year. I wouldn't call it stabilize, I just call it muted because we've got some thing that are very low levels like energy and then we've got wood cost that had
componenttext: This is Carol. I would say, on the input side, our overall view of input is fairly muted this year. I wouldn't call it stabilize, I just call it muted because we've got some thing that are very low levels like energy and then we've got wood cost that had more to do with mother nature and that seems a little bit stubbornly high, and I think Tim already mentioned the OCC. On the other side, general inflation, our goal, as I mentioned on our bridge on '15, our goal is to offset all the other inflation that we see each year with our initiatives in manufacturing. And that inflation number is probably in the range of 200 million to 225 million, and that's on people and services and whatnot. And our goal on that as it is every year for International Paper is to offset that just with running better and improvement, which we've been doing.

componenttext: Yes, I'll take the Ilim question. Paul, on Ilim, we've seen some trail off in pricing as we finish the year. We still see that's filling a little bit in the first quarter, but it seems like, first off, with pulp, things are beginning to stabilize. And so that's kind of how our view is right now. Ilim's interesting because even with pricing pressures, we also have ever improving cost position. So our margins on the financial aspect of the business are still very strong.
