componenttext: Just you signaled the pulp pressure, and I just wanted to get some comments with respect to Ilim and your North American business. And then just on North America, just the Riegelwood conversion. I understand the qualification for fluff by the end of the year, but how do you expect the absorption of that extra 400,000 tons into the market, i.e., when will it be done?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Mike Amick. In terms of the pulp, as Carol mentioned in her opening slide, we expect to be up and running in the May time frame and kind of fully ramped up in terms of the production of that machine in the last -- latter part of this year.
componenttext:
Paul, this is Mike Amick. In terms of the pulp, as Carol mentioned in her opening slide, we expect to be up and running in the May time frame and kind of fully ramped up in terms of the production of that machine in the last -- latter part of this year. 
In terms of the pressure that we're seeing out there, overall last year, as we look at strategically where we're focused and where we're growing, we had a good year in our fluff growth, delivering at about 4%, 4.5% on our growth. So we felt really good about that, which is hence the need for the incremental capacity and the growth that we've got planned for this year and going forward. 
On Ilim?

headline: International Paper Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll take the Ilim question, Mike. Thank you. Paul, on the Ilim, we've seen some trail-off in pricing as we finish the year. We still see that spilling a little into the first quarter. But it seems like for softwood pulp things are beginning to stabi
componenttext: Yes, I'll take the Ilim question, Mike. Thank you. Paul, on the Ilim, we've seen some trail-off in pricing as we finish the year. We still see that spilling a little into the first quarter. But it seems like for softwood pulp things are beginning to stabilize. And so that's kind of how our view is right now. Ilim's interesting because, even with pricing pressures, we also have an ever-improving cost position. So our margins and the financial aspects of the business are still very strong.

componenttext: Thanks, Jay. And I just wanted to kind of wrap up. We had a very robust discussion about '15 and also about our first quarter. I think we're well positioned to execute well. headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Brandy, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Paper First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And now I'd like to turn the call
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Brandy, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Paper First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. And now I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. Jay Royalty, Vice President of Investor Relations, to begin.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brandy, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining International Paper's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Our key speakers this morning are Mark Sutton, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Carol Roberts, Senior Vice
componenttext:
Thanks, Brandy, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining International Paper's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. 
Our key speakers this morning are Mark Sutton, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Carol Roberts, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are outlined on Slide 2 of our presentation. We will also present certain non-U.S. GAAP financial information. A reconciliation of those figures to U.S. GAAP financial measures are available on our website. 
Our website also contains copies of the first quarter 2016 earnings press release and today's presentation slides. 
Lastly, relative to the Ilim JV, Slide 4 provides context around the joint venture's financial information and statistical measures. 
With that, I'll now turn the call over to Mark Sutton.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call. I'm going to start on Slide 5. International Paper delivered solid first quarter driven by continued strong performance in our North American Industrial Packaging business, alon
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call. 
I'm going to start on Slide 5. International Paper delivered solid first quarter driven by continued strong performance in our North American Industrial Packaging business, along with improved results in our global papers business. Demand across our businesses was at or slightly better than expectations. Our operations performed well, and input costs were favorable. The Riegelwood conversion to fluff pulp was completed several days ago, and we have commenced start-up and qualifications. The Ilim JV had another strong quarter of results. And we announced a couple of important strategic moves, both of which will benefit IP's returns and are really all about making our best business, our Industrial Packaging business, even better. We reached a definitive agreement to sell our Asia Industrial Packaging business, which is expected to close in the second quarter. We also reached an agreement to acquire state-of-the-art newsprint mill in Spain from Holmen Paper, which we plan to convert to high-performance recycled linerboard to strengthen our value proposition to our customers and enhance the results for our European Industrial Packaging business. We plan to use all of that containerboard inside of our converting system. 
Turning to Slide 6. I'd just like to give you a little more color on our financial performance. IP's revenue declined a year-over-year. This was primarily due to the sale of the Sun joint venture in China, which took place in the fourth quarter of 2015. We also incurred cost of about $45 million, exclusive of outage expenses, associated with the Riegelwood conversion, and this was a significant drag to earnings in the quarter. Margins would have been about 100 basis points better, absent this impact. Our free cash flow $311 million was on par with last year's first quarter. 
At this point, what I'd like to do is turn it over to Carol, and she'll walk us through the performance of our individual businesses and the second quarter outlook. And then I'll return to wrap it up, and we'll open it up for your questions. Carol?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. As Mark mentioned, IP delivered a solid first quarter at $0.80 cents EPS with favorable operations and input cost, offset by lower prices, seasonally lower volumes and heavy maintenance outages, including the Rieg
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. As Mark mentioned, IP delivered a solid first quarter at $0.80 cents EPS with favorable operations and input cost, offset by lower prices, seasonally lower volumes and heavy maintenance outages, including the Riegelwood conversion. The positive swing at Ilim is FX related, primarily due to the strengthening of the ruble as it relates to the JV's U.S. dollar-denominated net debt. 
Turning to the businesses on Slide 8. Industrial Packaging, as Mark said, had a strong quarter. We had favorable operations and lower input cost, but they were mostly offset by lower export and box pricing, seasonally lower box volume as expected and higher plant maintenance outage expense. Export volumes did rebound from a weak fourth quarter. The North American business took 212 tons of economic downtime to balance our supply with our demand and adjust our need to match a more efficient supply chain. Input cost were positively impacted by lower cost of OCC and diesel fuel. 
Turning to Slide 9. IP's North American box demand came in generally as expected with year-over-year volume of 1.3% for the first quarter, which was in line with the industry. The quarter finished strong in March, and that momentum has continued through April. As you can see in the table, which highlights several of IP's key customer segment, we see several encouraging trends. We continue to see strong growth in online retail, which had become more meaningful for overall demand. The large process food segment is beginning to show some positive signs as the major companies are making moves to adjust to changing consumer preferences. The agricultural segment, to which IP is a major supplier, is enjoying the most favorable weather conditions the regions have seen in a few years, and this point to solid growth for 2016. And the outlook for the important protein segment is improving. So net-net, a fairly favorable outlook for the business. 
Turning to Europe. As Mark mentioned, we recently announced the strategic move to acquire a unique asset that can be converted to very effectively complement our corrugated packaging network in the region. This transaction will create significant value from both the customer offering and the financial standpoint as it will enable IP to produce high-performance, lightweight recycled containerboard in region. We will acquire the mill along with associated recycling operations and Holmen's ownership position in an on-site cogeneration facility. Upon closing of the deal, we will initiate plans for the conversion of the state-of-the-art newsprint machine to a first quartile testliner machine, which we expect to complete in late 2017. Once reconfigured, the machine will produce 420,000 short ton on recycled containerboard, which will enable IP to integrate the majority of our test liner needs. The total investment for the acquisition and conversion is expected to be approximately $160 million with an expected IRR of more than 15%. 
If you turn to Slide 11, in addition to the attractive age and technology of the machine as well as the mill's configuration, the location of the mill in relation to the majority of our box network is very attractive. The grades of high-performance test liner that we intend to produce on these machines have the greatest application for our broad base of industrial customers. And most of these our served out of our box plant in Spain, France and northern Italy, as shown on the highlighted area of the map. So once again, we're excited about the prospect of this movie and what it can do for our customers at International Paper. 
Turning now to Slide 12, let me talk about Consumer Packaging, where we saw a seasonally slower quarter combined with some pricing pressures, less favorable mix and heavier outage expense resulted in lower earnings for the business in the first quarter. Most of the pricing pressure was felt in the commodity price segment. The timing of volume and higher value mix in the foodservice consumers business was slower to materialize than we had expected as well. Additionally, the sale and exit of the coated bristols business negatively impacted results in the quarter. 
Now moving to Slide 13, and talking about our Printing Papers segment. The slide shows the sequential bridge for the entire segment, which does include our pulp business. As was mentioned earlier, the pulp impact of the Riegelwood conversion, along with the sub-optimized operation at Riegelwood as the conversion of PM18 was underway, significantly impacted segment results for the first quarter by approximately $45 million in total. We will continue to see cost impact from the conversion in the second quarter, along with start-up and qualification cost that will continue to impact results in the second quarter and the second half of 2016. This is consistent with the outlook we provided last quarter and is fully captured in the outlook that I'll share with you shortly. 
Slide 14 shows the results of the global paper segment, excluding pulp and the impact of the conversion. Volume was seasonally weaker as we expected, largely in Brazil, while demand in North America was solid. Good operations and lower input cost contributed favorably to the result as in lower plant maintenance outage expense. Prices were lower in North America, but higher in Europe, Russia and Brazil as we plan to see the benefit of the implementation of previously announced price increases. And price increases are announced in North America and are being implemented in the second quarter. 
Let me give a little more color on Riegelwood. As Mark said, we are pleased that the conversion has been completed on-time and on budget in the month of April, and the start up and qualification of the machine have commenced. Production of softwood market pulp is underway, and then we'll move to the qualification of fluff pulp. We expect to begin fluff trials in the third quarter. The current pricing environment for softwood market pulp, which is used for paper towel and tissue products, is under pressure in the near term. As we ramp up and produce SPFK on the new machine through the rest of 2016, these current conditions will adversely affect earnings. This will improve as we qualify fluff pulp on the new machine and optimize production across our system. 
Turning now to the Ilim JV. The JV had another very strong quarter with operational EBITDA of $176 million, a strong manufacturing performance partially offset lower pulp prices and seasonally lower volume. Over the course of the first quarter, the ruble strengthened slightly against the dollar, which resulted in a favorable noncash FX gain on the JV's $600 million of U.S. denominated net debt, and that impacted our first quarter earnings favorably by $0.03 per share. Lower pulp prices and seasonally higher wood cost, along with planned maintenance outages at the Bratsk and Koryazhma mills are expected to negatively impact second quarter results. 
So before I turn it back over to Mark, let me give you the second quarter outlook. Earnings will increase due to seasonally higher volume in North American box and Brazil papers. The additional box volume is expected to favorably impact North American Industrial Packaging earnings by roughly $40 million. The impact of seasonally stronger demand in Brazil is expected to positively impact earnings by $10 million. 
Moving on to pricing in North America. The expected impact of lower pulp prices and a less favorable mix, associated with the ramp up of Riegelwood on softwood pulp in the second quarter, is about a negative $20 million. This is net of the benefits of the previously announced price increases in uncoated free sheet in North America. Pricing for North American Industrial Packaging will be impacted by lower export pricing, along with the flow through of the January PPW index change that will move through the box. To mind, this is expected to negatively impact earnings in the range of $25 million to $30 million. Prices are expected to improve in Brazil papers as the previous announced price increases are implemented. This will favorably impact earnings by about $10 million. Operational cost in North American Industrial Packaging are expected to improve as a result of seasonally stronger demand and utilization, along with other cost reduction and improvement initiatives. This will be a benefit of roughly $30 million. Operational cost across the other businesses are expected to remain favorable, and input costs are expected to remain generally favorable as well, although we do expect some slight pressure in Europe. Maintenance outage expenses will continue to be heavy in the second quarter but are expected to decrease by a total of $22 million as shown on the slide, mainly due to the lower outage cost at Riegelwood. And relative to the Ilim JV, the items you see on the chart are expected to negatively impact IP equity earnings by approximately $10 million to $15 million. And additionally, we are assuming stable FX coming out of the quarter. As you know, we don't attempt to forecast currency. So the outlook assumes a nonrepeat of the $0.03 gain from the first quarter. 
So with that overview, let me turn it back over to Mark.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Carol. So let me wrap things up before we take your question. I feel really good about our execution and results from the first quarter, and I'm encouraged that demand feels more favorable across the primary markets that we serve. Our focus remain
componenttext:
Thanks, Carol. So let me wrap things up before we take your question. I feel really good about our execution and results from the first quarter, and I'm encouraged that demand feels more favorable across the primary markets that we serve. Our focus remains on execution, and we saw a benefit from our efforts in the first quarter in terms of good operational performance and lower cost. The conversion at Riegelwood went well, was on-time and on budget, and our team is now ramping up and qualifying the new capabilities. All of this will enable International Paper to continue to generate strong free cash flow which will allow it to create additional value. We've also made some key decisions that will improve IP's portfolio and make it stronger, and further improve returns on invested capital, mainly our decisions in Asia and Madrid. And you'll see more of this as we move forward where it make sense for International Paper and our stakeholders. We have winning strategies in the right markets, and our focus is clear as you're seeing in the moves we are making. We're focused on producing products where we have a distinct advantage with good access to fiber and low-cost manufacturing. We're concentrating our efforts on the markets and product lines that give IP the greatest potential to generate meaningful earnings and attractive returns. 
So with that, I'll turn it back over to the operator, and we'll be happy to take your questions.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Adam Josephson from KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Adam Josephson from KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark and Carol, just 2-part question from my first question. Are you still -- do you expect D&A expenses of $1.3 billion this year just given that they fell a bit below what I was expecting this quarter? And relatedly, your EBITDA was down 14% in the firs
componenttext: Mark and Carol, just 2-part question from my first question. Are you still -- do you expect D&A expenses of $1.3 billion this year just given that they fell a bit below what I was expecting this quarter? And relatedly, your EBITDA was down 14% in the first quarter. Do you still think you can be close to flat this year? Or if not, what do you think reasonable expectations are along those lines for EBITDA?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam, this is Carol, and I'll take the first one on the D&A. Yes, we do still expect to be in the range of $1.3 billion. What happens is there's some variability to it when you have no down for outages, you stop your depreciation for that period of time,
componenttext: Adam, this is Carol, and I'll take the first one on the D&A. Yes, we do still expect to be in the range of $1.3 billion. What happens is there's some variability to it when you have no down for outages, you stop your depreciation for that period of time, so it's just really just some lumpiness in it. But overall, $1.3 billion is still a good number for the year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam, on EBITDA, your question about how we fill around the flat year-over-year. It's obviously got some stretch in it with some of the pricing headwinds that have occurred. But at the same time, as I mentioned in my comments, we feel really good about ou
componenttext: Adam, on EBITDA, your question about how we fill around the flat year-over-year. It's obviously got some stretch in it with some of the pricing headwinds that have occurred. But at the same time, as I mentioned in my comments, we feel really good about our execution and our ability to make improvement in our businesses, both commercially and operationally. So I think we're very much still in the range of being able to accomplish that. We've got a lot of the year left, and we've got some real positive trends on our commercial front, and we're operating very, very well.  So we're all about focus on hitting that EBITDA that we talked about.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And just one on containerboard exports. Can you just comment -- forgive me if I missed this on what your export volumes were sequentially and year-over-year. Obviously, the trade press has talked about the export prices falling to cash cost for so
componenttext: Thanks. And just one on containerboard exports. Can you just comment -- forgive me if I missed this on what your export volumes were sequentially and year-over-year. Obviously, the trade press has talked about the export prices falling to cash cost for some of the higher cost mills in the U.S, I'm just hoping you can address this issue.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Tim. Demand actually is holding up reasonably well in the fourth quarter, I think we called out -- our volume was down, we called out some reasons around that, that were situational, and we thought temporary in the first quarter we saw a rebound in e
componenttext: It's Tim. Demand actually is holding up reasonably well in the fourth quarter, I think we called out -- our volume was down, we called out some reasons around that, that were situational, and we thought temporary in the first quarter we saw a rebound in export volumes. We were still a little bit lower in total than we were in the first quarter last year. Part of that, in fact, a big part of it is really Turkey and the dumping tariffs that has been imposed and just simply how we're thinking about our participation in the market. It's still a very key market for us, but not every account there is equal. And so we made some decisions in terms of how we were going to position ourselves in the first quarter and going forward. I'd say demand is good. Price gets written about a lot. It doesn't feel like our experience is quite as negative as all the things that has written about it. But there's no doubt, there's some competitive situations out there, and there is a little bit of price pressure. That will probably continue as we go to the second quarter.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next question though comes from Dr. Mark Wilde of BMO.
componenttext: You're next question though comes from Dr. Mark Wilde of BMO.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I wondered if you guys -- maybe you and Tim, could just help us a little bit as we think about sort of this PPW adjustments back in February, and how they kind of roll through kind of first quarter, second quarter and into the second half?
componenttext: Mark, I wondered if you guys -- maybe you and Tim, could just help us a little bit as we think about sort of this PPW adjustments back in February, and how they kind of roll through kind of first quarter, second quarter and into the second half?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Mark, I'll let Tim take that.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, Carol kind of spotted the number. It was fairly minimal in the first quarter. We're dealing customer-by-customer and contract-by-contract, and they don't all work exactly the same way. And given the timing of the PPW adjustment in the first q
componenttext: Yes, I mean, Carol kind of spotted the number. It was fairly minimal in the first quarter. We're dealing customer-by-customer and contract-by-contract, and they don't all work exactly the same way. And given the timing of the PPW adjustment in the first quarter, not very much of it that flowed through in the quarter. It will ramp up in the second quarter, and Carol pointed out a combination of PPW and export being between $25 million and $30 million. The bulk of that, we think, is because of the price adjustment with the index. And we'll talk to you about third and fourth quarter as we go through the year, as we continue to work through all of the customer contracts. So -- but you'll see a fairly significant step up first to second.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, as we think about trying to model out the third and fourth quarter, will it be fair to assume some kind of bleed through peering in the third and fourth quarter?
componenttext: Tim, as we think about trying to model out the third and fourth quarter, will it be fair to assume some kind of bleed through peering in the third and fourth quarter?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Possibly. It's hard try to say, Mark. I mean I'd rather us do the work and get through it and then talk to you about what we think it will be in the third quarter as we finish the second quarter the same way we did going into this quarter.
componenttext: Possibly. It's hard try to say, Mark. I mean I'd rather us do the work and get through it and then talk to you about what we think it will be in the third quarter as we finish the second quarter the same way we did going into this quarter.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, that's fair. Just staying on the containerboard and Industrial Packaging business, you've taken about 440,000 tons of economic downtime over the last 6 months. I wondered if you can talk about how you're taking that? Are you slowing back or you
componenttext: All right, that's fair. Just staying on the containerboard and Industrial Packaging business, you've taken about 440,000 tons of economic downtime over the last 6 months. I wondered if you can talk about how you're taking that? Are you slowing back or you're actually idling machines for a week or 2 here or there? And is there a point where you need to consider a longer-term move on the supply side?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll see. I think the power of what we're doing is the power of the system and the flexibility that we've built. And some of the investments that we're making, it's all around building capability and flexibility in the system. We know that when you
componenttext: Well, we'll see. I think the power of what we're doing is the power of the system and the flexibility that we've built. And some of the investments that we're making, it's all around building capability and flexibility in the system. We know that when you're stretching the system in terms of utilization rate, things don't always work out the way you want them to, and we've built a tremendous amount of flexibility and a very strong system. So I can't say what it will be going forward. What I can say is we look over a multi-period -- multiple periods, out months at a time, not just within a quarter, and we target where we think we need to be in terms of how we run the system. And then we adjust that almost day-to-day and week-to-week based on a variety of factors. One thing that happened in the fourth quarter, really late third, and continues to be a factor is just how efficiently the supply chain network is running right now. And so what it's meant for us at a moment in time is we just need lots of inventory, and so we've adjusted our production accordingly to match that. We'll have to monitor that over time. Things don’t stay the same. They have a tendency to move around, so we'll have to see how supply chain performs through the rest of the year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, if I could just add to Tim's comment. One of the things we've learned as our system has been optimized and it's gotten as large as it gotten, we clearly create more value in our containerboard and box system when there is a bit of flexibility in the
componenttext: Mark, if I could just add to Tim's comment. One of the things we've learned as our system has been optimized and it's gotten as large as it gotten, we clearly create more value in our containerboard and box system when there is a bit of flexibility in the system and we create less value when we try to run everything to its limits. And I mean, commercial volume and our ability to respond to customers, running efficient box network, and also actual cost value in properly maintaining the equipment before the expensive failures occurs. And so that few percent on maintenance and that few percent on economic flexibility, economic downtime, really ends up creating the best opportunity for us to generate the highest margins. So it's something that we don't look to sell to 0, because I think if it was 0, we will have a very difficult commercial proposition for our customers.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Steve Chercover of D. A. Davidson.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Steve Chercover of D. A. Davidson.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question. I want to ask about the announcement of a new fluff pulp mill in Arkansas that cost $1.3 billion. Will that seriously upset the supply-demand dynamic? And what does it say about the value of fluff pulp asset perhaps?
componenttext: First question. I want to ask about the announcement of a new fluff pulp mill in Arkansas that cost $1.3 billion. Will that seriously upset the supply-demand dynamic? And what does it say about the value of fluff pulp asset perhaps?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, we saw that. We have a little bit of knowledge about the background there. It's hard to predict what that facility is going to do and when. I think fluff pulp is a highly technical product. You have to have a customer list and a track record. So it
componenttext: Steve, we saw that. We have a little bit of knowledge about the background there. It's hard to predict what that facility is going to do and when. I think fluff pulp is a highly technical product. You have to have a customer list and a track record. So it will be an open question about whether or not a mill that can make the products actually ends up with a large book of business in that. And there are different degrees of absorbent products that are loosely lumped into fluff. What we concentrate on is the higher end, high performance products that are medical device type of products. So I can't speculate on what that particular company is going to try to do. But obviously, there is a lot to being successful in fluff pulp over the long time, over the long term, primarily because of the branded nature of the consumer product that it goes into. And we've been at it for a while and have a premium customer list that wants us to continue to provide them new material.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Did you want to take the bait on the value fluff pulp asset in general?
componenttext: Did you want to take the bait on the value fluff pulp asset in general?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I must not have because I didn't. No, I think my comments on all fluff not created equal, and there are types products I think should characterize the value of fluff pulp is a highly valuable product given the technical nature of it and the consumer brand
componenttext: I must not have because I didn't. No, I think my comments on all fluff not created equal, and there are types products I think should characterize the value of fluff pulp is a highly valuable product given the technical nature of it and the consumer branded equity that's behind of those products that it goes into.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: I think will show that the report in the quarter was $100 million, and I'm looking at my colleagues here on the final share count. But I think you can factor in the $100 million purchase, and that's what we did in the quarter. So it's continuing to move down, and our intent is to continue to be opportunistic with our buyback.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Post Riegelwood, I would imagine that a very large chunk of your business is more on the food service side, which is holding up okay, I would especially pulp side. But with the PPW kind of SBS, is it about 40% of your business that gets impacted? And how should we think about the lag in terms of it flowing through your P&L?

componenttext: This is Mike. Yes, the number is going to be roughly 30% to 35% of our business, could potentially be impacted by that in 2016. And we primarily see this being a second half phenomenon.

componenttextpreview: Second half phenomenon. Okay, and how do you guys characterize demand in the board market? I mean, certainly, Riegelwood should help, but I guess one of your competitors did bring back an idle mill, and then you get some of that potential capacity coming
componenttext: Second half phenomenon. Okay, and how do you guys characterize demand in the board market? I mean, certainly, Riegelwood should help, but I guess one of your competitors did bring back an idle mill, and then you get some of that potential capacity coming its way in the U.S. market from European. So how do you guys think about supply demand, medium to longer term?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike again, I would characterize the demand is okay. I don't know that I'd use the term not really strong. But through the quarter, we've seen improving backlogs and order backlogs by almost 50% as we move through the quarter. So I think, I know i
componenttext: This is Mike again, I would characterize the demand is okay. I don't know that I'd use the term not really strong. But through the quarter, we've seen improving backlogs and order backlogs by almost 50% as we move through the quarter. So I think, I know it right now kind of sitting where we are and the first part of April, we're about where we were this time last year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just one last one for me. Mark, you talked about how demand in the quarter for containerboard kind of firmed up with ag picking up and e-commerce certainly seeing a lift as well. Can you remind us how you're thinking about box shipments for the
componenttext: Okay, and just one last one for me. Mark, you talked about how demand in the quarter for containerboard kind of firmed up with ag picking up and e-commerce certainly seeing a lift as well. Can you remind us how you're thinking about box shipments for the full year now in light of the strength you're seeing in 1Q?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Tim take that.
componenttext: I'll let Tim take that.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think last quarter, we said we thought it would be for the full year for a total market 1% to 1.5%. I don’t think our view has changed that much. I would say that we did see the quarter strengthen as we went through the first quarter. And March w
componenttext: Yes, I think last quarter, we said we thought it would be for the full year for a total market 1% to 1.5%. I don’t think our view has changed that much. I would say that we did see the quarter strengthen as we went through the first quarter. And March was very strong for us. April continues to be very strong for us. Right now, month to date, we're in the up 2% range. So some of these segments that have been weighing against us over the past few quarters are starting to turn hopefully, and we'll see if it holds up, we feel pretty good right now.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think Tim's point, every organization has a mix, customer mix. And we like what we've seen in some of the trends of the mix that's particularly heavy for International Paper. So that should lead us to tracking a lot more consistent with what the ov
componenttext: Yes, I think Tim's point, every organization has a mix, customer mix. And we like what we've seen in some of the trends of the mix that's particularly heavy for International Paper. So that should lead us to tracking a lot more consistent with what the overall market is doing this is maybe our past experience. So we feel good about that.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the mix dynamic with protein potentially picking up in the back half cycle turning, that should be a positive for you guys as well? Are we thinking about that right?
componenttext: And the mix dynamic with protein potentially picking up in the back half cycle turning, that should be a positive for you guys as well? Are we thinking about that right?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. Protein, hopefully, has stabilized, and we'll see how it plays out the rest of the year. Processed food, actually, for us, on the mix of customers that we have, trended pretty favorably during the first quarter, and looks like it's holdin
componenttext: Yes, I think so. Protein, hopefully, has stabilized, and we'll see how it plays out the rest of the year. Processed food, actually, for us, on the mix of customers that we have, trended pretty favorably during the first quarter, and looks like it's holding up in the second quarter. I mean, I'm not going to go into specifics, but we saw individual names being up 2%, 3%, 4%, 4-plus percent in the quarter, and it got stronger as we went through the quarter. So it's ag. California's getting rain, that's a good thing. So we're well positioned in that part of the market. And then everybody likes to talk about e-commerce, but it's really distribution. We got a mix of customers across the e-commerce space as well as distribution and a strong pretty good strength across the board.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mark Weintraub of Buckingham Research.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: One quick follow up on the DD&A question from before. I saw that the Consumer Packaging business was down quite a bit. Was that all Riegelwood? And I know that the pulp haven't gone up, does that go up once the conversion has taken place?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mark. What we did is we moved that mill, Riegelwood, which was a shared mill be between the 2 segments, both coated paperboard segment and the paper segment. And that's now moved all the way over to NAPP. So it's less coated paperboard, hence the cha
componenttext: Yes, Mark. What we did is we moved that mill, Riegelwood, which was a shared mill be between the 2 segments, both coated paperboard segment and the paper segment. And that's now moved all the way over to NAPP. So it's less coated paperboard, hence the change there. And since with the mill down, most of the quarter for the conversion and their actual annual outage, that's what you saw. So that will now show up in the NAPP segment.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so the Consumer Packaging runs just like $25 million a quarter now in North America and $45 million that it had then for DD&A?
componenttext: Okay, so the Consumer Packaging runs just like $25 million a quarter now in North America and $45 million that it had then for DD&A?

componenttext: Yes.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on uncoated free sheet, is it fair to say that you are not reflecting a lot of impact from the price increase, which is just currently underway in the second quarter, and saw success on that? If it comes through, would it largely show up in
componenttext: Okay. And then on uncoated free sheet, is it fair to say that you are not reflecting a lot of impact from the price increase, which is just currently underway in the second quarter, and saw success on that? If it comes through, would it largely show up in the third quarter? And maybe if you can modify a little bit.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Well, Mark, yes, you're accurate in your statement. It will be -- we started to see a little bit -- we'll start to see a little bit in the second quarter, but it will be primarily be a second half event. And yes, primarily split between the third and latter part of the third quarter, maybe a little in the fourth.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Staphos of Bank of America.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of questions. I guess, first of all, in industrial. Can you update us on your thoughts as to how you might be able to increase your vertical integration? Are you saying opportunities for investment, either organically or through M&A to be a
componenttext: I had a couple of questions. I guess, first of all, in industrial. Can you update us on your thoughts as to how you might be able to increase your vertical integration? Are you saying opportunities for investment, either organically or through M&A to be able to accelerate that, if that's still a goal? And then that related point on the containerboard. Do you have a need for any similar moves like you did with Holmen? And what are the implications of that investment relative to your supply chain in North America? And then I have a quick follow on, if possible.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on your first question, George, it's Tim here. On integration -- I would say, we like all of the channels that we're  in. We operate in multiple channels. Obviously, the integrated the channels is the largest, and it's very important to us. It's goin
componenttext: Yes, on your first question, George, it's Tim here. On integration -- I would say, we like all of the channels that we're  in. We operate in multiple channels. Obviously, the integrated the channels is the largest, and it's very important to us. It's going to come down to how we win accounts in the marketplace and align ourselves with customers within segments. So there is no stated specific goal that we have to reach, a certain integration level. Acquisitions, we don't comment on the speculations, but we look at a lot of things. And so we'll continue to do that, and if one makes sense, then we'll be talking to everyone about what it is and why we think it makes sense. In terms of Holmen, don't expect a big impact from one region to another at all. But the related question around, are there are things like that? I think that's what you see us doing some of these investment that we're making. We've talked about increasing capacity and adding flexibility. It's not that all capacity is the same. What we're doing is we're adding capability around certain products that we think are going through our segments, and we think we need, and we're building that capability. So it's similar to Holmen, it's just different. We've got 16 mills where we can look at the product mix that we need and make investments accordingly.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next question comes from the line of Mark Kahlberg [ph] of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: You're next question comes from the line of Mark Kahlberg [ph] of Credit Suisse.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question actually on the Holmen transaction. When I'm looking at your investor package business in Europe, the problem seems to be that you have very low margins in your box business. This doesn't necessarily fix up problems. So how do we -- are yo
componenttext: Just a question actually on the Holmen transaction. When I'm looking at your investor package business in Europe, the problem seems to be that you have very low margins in your box business. This doesn't necessarily fix up problems. So how do we -- are you thinking about addressing that business in itself because just adding upstream integration doesn't necessarily fix what seems to be a low-margin business?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mark. The way -- building on Tim's comment about channel, the way we look at our European corrugated business is a very focused business. We look at it as one of our channels to market. We move very high quality, high performance kraftliners throu
componenttext: This is Mark. The way -- building on Tim's comment about channel, the way we look at our European corrugated business is a very focused business. We look at it as one of our channels to market. We move very high quality, high performance kraftliners through that system. If you look at the geography, we're focused on fresh foods. And so our view of that business is part of our integrated channel to market. And the integration of high-performance recycled liner, coupled with our U.S. produced high-performance Kraft liner makes that whole value proposition better. It allows us to improve our customer mix. And as you know from the European theater, the recycled board that's available is graphically available. So you have to have what you need, where you need it in a reliable way to build out your offering for your customers. And that's what this does to improve that business. So what we focus on in our European corrugated business is very good for the company, and when you take it back and look at the way we think about Industrial Packaging globally, it's a really good business for IP.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on that. I mean, there's a tremendous amount of conversions that hits the market [indiscernible] on 17 out of the 18, we're talking about almost 2 million tons. Is that a consideration at all for you us a non-integrated system today? Is t
componenttext: Just a follow-up on that. I mean, there's a tremendous amount of conversions that hits the market [indiscernible] on 17 out of the 18, we're talking about almost 2 million tons. Is that a consideration at all for you us a non-integrated system today? Is the right time to do it?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that phenomenal large has been sort of a fixture in the European market. There's been a couple of million tons overhang. The problem with that statement is, it's on average, and again, recycled high-performance liner, it's not all created equal, the
componenttext: Well, that phenomenal large has been sort of a fixture in the European market. There's been a couple of million tons overhang. The problem with that statement is, it's on average, and again, recycled high-performance liner, it's not all created equal, there are 3 or 4 grade levels, including medium. And so what has to happen is converted International Paper has to have what we need, where we need it. So if it's in the north of Europe, its theoretical. Even if it's in overhang, it doesn't really affect. So what you have to look at is regional capacity. And we've been a large open market buyer for a long period of time. And we will still buy some. But that's how we look at it. Regional board for the conversion that you need in the market segment that you're focused on, not the average of containerboard supply and demand for all of Europe, which is a very diverse market, especially for the recycled liner.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mark Connelly at CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mark Connelly at CLSA.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick things. Can you give us an update on the timing of the 250,000 tons of new containerboard capacity that you're adding here? You talked about it is a gradual ramp. I'm just wondering if you could give us some signpost and tell us when that wil
componenttext: Just 2 quick things. Can you give us an update on the timing of the 250,000 tons of new containerboard capacity that you're adding here? You talked about it is a gradual ramp. I'm just wondering if you could give us some signpost and tell us when that will be up and running. And second, it looks like you've cut your containerboard maintenance numbers. Is that a change in scope or just improved efficiency?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Tim. On the first question, capacity, there's really no difference than what we said at the time we announced. We said it's going to be a '16, '17 set of actions. So I don't know if it it's half half, but you'll see some of it come through this year,
componenttext: It's Tim. On the first question, capacity, there's really no difference than what we said at the time we announced. We said it's going to be a '16, '17 set of actions. So I don't know if it it's half half, but you'll see some of it come through this year, and you'll see a little bit more come through in the first half of next year. And then on maintenance. Maintenance varies mill by mill and period-to-period. There's a plan, there's a schedule that goes out years, and you look at it piece of equipment by piece of equipment. It just happens that you will hit periods when the things that need to be tended to in an annual outage cost more because of the nature of the work in a given period than in others.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would add to that, Mark, this is Carol, is, while you do see that reduction from the last time we forecasted the second quarter down is we know as a company that we've got headwinds, and so what we've been trying to do, of course, you got to find ot
componenttext: And I would add to that, Mark, this is Carol, is, while you do see that reduction from the last time we forecasted the second quarter down is we know as a company that we've got headwinds, and so what we've been trying to do, of course, you got to find other levers to pull. And as Tim said, he's looking at the system very hard to make sure he's doing what he needs to do, and if there's an opportunity to do some things up to get more money to the bottom line, that's what we're attempting to do. And we'll continue to disclose that each quarter so just you can follow and track those changes.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Mark Sutton. Just the question -- the first question you asked. Just to tie it back to an earlier question around how we run our system. That incremental capacity capability that's coming from these investments, as Tim mentioned, it's really
componenttext: Mark, this is Mark Sutton. Just the question -- the first question you asked. Just to tie it back to an earlier question around how we run our system. That incremental capacity capability that's coming from these investments, as Tim mentioned, it's really about making some products differently than we've made before, making our system more flexible, meaning we can make similar products at the similar mill at the same mail or a different mill, so we can improve our supply chain. So the issue of capacity coming online is only when and if we needed for the demand environment. It's really the driver is really making more of this and less of that for the boxes that we need to make going forward. And as an outcome of improving those facilities, we have more capacity if we need more capacity. So that's kind of the way to think about it as opposed to this is coming on this at this date, and this is coming on at that date. It's coming as a new product and a new basis week, and new design. And net capacity on if you have the orders for it, doesn't come on if we don't have the orders for it.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Scott Gaffner from Barclays.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: This is actually John Dunigan filling in for Scott Gaffner. Most of my questions, unfortunately, have been asked, but I just have a couple. The figure I wanted to ask about, what you guys are seeing in the OCC prices? And how the lower input have had an impact on your first quarter and then what you're expecting in terms of an outlook going forward for that? And how it affects IP?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think our forecast the see some modest pressure in OCC pricing as we go through the second quarter. We don't expect it at this point to be a major factor in. And yes, in the first quarter, inputs were a bit of a tailwind for us which we are
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think our forecast the see some modest pressure in OCC pricing as we go through the second quarter. We don't expect it at this point to be a major factor in. And yes, in the first quarter, inputs were a bit of a tailwind for us which we are operating in a certain environment and trying to take advantage of the environment that we have.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And some of your peers had discussed some of the freight benefits that they've been enjoying, particularly getting some discounts and even building up on some inventory that can be -- just in time demand. Could you just touch upon on what IP is seei
componenttext: Okay. And some of your peers had discussed some of the freight benefits that they've been enjoying, particularly getting some discounts and even building up on some inventory that can be -- just in time demand. Could you just touch upon on what IP is seeing in terms of those cost and how you guys are maybe taking advantage, particularly in your industrial and packaging sector?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think part of what you've seen, just in what we've seen in terms of our supply chain network is rail and truck availability has improved dramatically and the last part of last year, early this year compared to where we were, say, a year ago. So that's o
componenttext: I think part of what you've seen, just in what we've seen in terms of our supply chain network is rail and truck availability has improved dramatically and the last part of last year, early this year compared to where we were, say, a year ago. So that's obviously having an impact on the discussions you have with carriers about rate structures. It's still a very challenged environment in some cases in terms of those discussions. But the are -- we think we are having some measure of traction as we have these discussions. The bigger impact in the moment is just what it means to how we think about our stocking positions across 200-plus facilities and its meaning at the moment that we need less inventory and we can run a much more efficient supply chain. So there's benefit in that. I think what we worry about is how it changes over time and will there be a snapback of utilization rates around carriers later this year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you generally think in the near term here that you can still enjoy the benefits with possibly a snapback late this year or maybe early next year?
componenttext: And you generally think in the near term here that you can still enjoy the benefits with possibly a snapback late this year or maybe early next year?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know when it's going to happen or if will happen. I just know that things don't stay static. People take actions. And so we don't count on anything lasting. I think it goes back to the power of the system. We have tremendous flexibility, and we're
componenttext: I don't know when it's going to happen or if will happen. I just know that things don't stay static. People take actions. And so we don't count on anything lasting. I think it goes back to the power of the system. We have tremendous flexibility, and we're trying to create more flexibly through these investments so that we can pull back when we need to, and we can recover quickly if we need to.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Debbie Jones of Deutsche Bank.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk about the change you made to your management incentive plan in early February? It looks like you switched it up based on 50% operating cash flow, 50% EBITDA with ROIC being the remainder. Is there anything we should read
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk about the change you made to your management incentive plan in early February? It looks like you switched it up based on 50% operating cash flow, 50% EBITDA with ROIC being the remainder. Is there anything we should read into that about your cash operating expenses in the coming years?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mark. I think what we're attempting to do there is cash flow is still front and center. What we got in that particular annual plan is focused on the majority of our employees who are running our operations, and the level and type of job, and we al
componenttext: This is Mark. I think what we're attempting to do there is cash flow is still front and center. What we got in that particular annual plan is focused on the majority of our employees who are running our operations, and the level and type of job, and we all talk in EBITDA in the company, that's where our plans are based on, that's what people are measured on. And we had a little bit of slippage in our EBITDA progress over the last couple of years. So it's just an attempt to focused on the overall scheme of things obviously, cash from ops starts with good to strong EBITDA, and then you go to the cash flow, free cash flow and our capital allocation strategy is clearly understood, commitment to the dividend. So no message other than focusing the people who are actually on that plan to look at ways we can improve our EBITDA and break through the flat nature of it over the last couple of years. So that's one plan for 1 year for a certain group of employees.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I just ask, do you still expect no pension contribution in 2016 and 2017?
componenttext: Can I just ask, do you still expect no pension contribution in 2016 and 2017?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Debbie, what I would say is we have a no required pension contributions for 2016 and 2017. How we go forward will obviously navigate that as we move forward.
componenttext: Debbie, what I would say is we have a no required pension contributions for 2016 and 2017. How we go forward will obviously navigate that as we move forward.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my last question, I just wanted to ask, we talked a lot about the substitution potential from kraftliner to your recycled liner and whether or not there's room to go just given the sustainably low OCC prices? And you see this from both vant
componenttext: Okay. And then my last question, I just wanted to ask, we talked a lot about the substitution potential from kraftliner to your recycled liner and whether or not there's room to go just given the sustainably low OCC prices? And you see this from both vantage points having exposure to both markets. I was wondering if you could just comment on this, and then also how this might impact your longer-term capacity plans?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Tim. We see in certain regions and certain areas, there's either more or less competition from certain type of the product range. I think the way we think about it is, we're looking with our customers that best fit and best use for the packaging they
componenttext: It's Tim. We see in certain regions and certain areas, there's either more or less competition from certain type of the product range. I think the way we think about it is, we're looking with our customers that best fit and best use for the packaging they need. And it includes a variety of substrates, some virgin, some recycled, fit for use. But it also includes capability, geography, service levels. And so we're selling them more than just is it recycled or is it virgin, we're selling them a total product. And we've got the breadth of products to do it like no other. So there's always going to be competition, it's a very competitive market, but we feel good about the value propositions we have.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then the question about the capital plan in the future, just thinking about the tonnage that you're adding in the coming years?
componenttext: And then the question about the capital plan in the future, just thinking about the tonnage that you're adding in the coming years?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't want to speculate on what we will do or won't do. We've got lowest OCC input cost at the moment, it's a moment in time. We think there's probably a different trend over time. And we'll make decisions. It's like I talked about these capacity a
componenttext: Yes, I don't want to speculate on what we will do or won't do. We've got lowest OCC input cost at the moment, it's a moment in time. We think there's probably a different trend over time. And we'll make decisions. It's like I talked about these capacity additions. We're not just adding generic tons,  we're adding products and grades and basis weights for where we see growth in our channels and the types of products that we need to support that growth. So -- and then we run it accordingly, as we've said, to what our demand is. So we'll continue -- we constantly look at what are those products, what do they need to be, where should we add them, and then it will be an ongoing evaluation.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Chris Manuel of Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Manuel of Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two topics I kind of wanted to touch on. First, a little bit more around, you're probably tired talking about it, but some of the dynamics here with North American containerboard, and the second topic being Ilim. So with respect to the first topic, I mean
componenttext: Two topics I kind of wanted to touch on. First, a little bit more around, you're probably tired talking about it, but some of the dynamics here with North American containerboard, and the second topic being Ilim. So with respect to the first topic, I mean, I hear kind of how you answered the quip Debbie in March and if you notice questions around things. But could you maybe, if I look at the downtime you took in 4Q and 1Q, one quarter doesn't make a trend but it's now been 2 in a row that it's been solidly north of 200,000 tons. If we kind of annualized that, that's larger than a machine close to a mill, 900,000-ish tons on an annual basis of downtime  market downtime. You also kind of referenced you have some inventories coming down. So maybe you could help us, give us a sense as to, when I look at inventory -- or industry inventory, they haven't really moved much the last few months, but maybe you're has. Could you give us a sense maybe either in tons or in week supply or however you think about your inventories have changed in 3Q to 4Q to 1Q?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, we run a very tight supply chain year round, and we make adjustments as we go. So no, I'm not going to break out tons or weeks of supply. I'm just going to say that we're constantly looking out 4, 5 months in advance targeting where we think
componenttext: I would say, we run a very tight supply chain year round, and we make adjustments as we go. So no, I'm not going to break out tons or weeks of supply. I'm just going to say that we're constantly looking out 4, 5 months in advance targeting where we think we need based on our demand signal, and then we make adjustments as we run the system. So the downtime that we took in the fourth quarter and first quarter, a very large component of that goes back to supply chain efficiencies and just not needing as much inventory through our chain. That could change over time and maybe we're taking a little bit of risk on the downside in terms of how we it might change and what we might do to be able to do to respond to it. But we just like to run a very tight supply chain, and we'll continue to do so.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if I read into that, it sounds like your inventory levels over the last couple of quarters have come down a good chunk then, and are not flat?
componenttext: So if I read into that, it sounds like your inventory levels over the last couple of quarters have come down a good chunk then, and are not flat?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, they're not thought. And a lot of things go into targeting inventory levels. We run hundreds and hundreds, if not thousands, of grades, 200 locations. And so we're looking product-by-product, basis, weights, grades, locations in the stocking levels ac
componenttext: No, they're not thought. And a lot of things go into targeting inventory levels. We run hundreds and hundreds, if not thousands, of grades, 200 locations. And so we're looking product-by-product, basis, weights, grades, locations in the stocking levels across all of those, and then we're adjusting the system accordingly. And it takes less time to get products for most of the box plants because of the velocity has increased, then we obviously don't need as much inventory in the system.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. And with respect to Ilim, I've read several places, it looks like you can do a pretty sizable expansion there. Could you maybe give us a little color as to what's happening in timing and things of that nature and as well as while that's g
componenttext: Okay, thank you. And with respect to Ilim, I've read several places, it looks like you can do a pretty sizable expansion there. Could you maybe give us a little color as to what's happening in timing and things of that nature and as well as while that's going on, what we would probably expect out of -- would dividend stop for a while or how might that work?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Chris, on the Ilim, I think you're referencing, they put out a 5-year plan, and it was a capital plan to improve the business. A big portion of that is inclusive of their normal maintenance and regulatory CapEx. That's about $325 million annually. So t
componenttext: So Chris, on the Ilim, I think you're referencing, they put out a 5-year plan, and it was a capital plan to improve the business. A big portion of that is inclusive of their normal maintenance and regulatory CapEx. That's about $325 million annually. So the incremental that was in that announcement over that 5-year period was about $700 million. And it's planned only as the projects are developed and as they have the right returns, to improve the current business that they have and to improve the quality of the product, and if necessary, to make more product at a second facility. And the plan for that would be to organize the funding the same way, the prior development of Ilim was done, which was on the Ilim balance sheet, and we don't see any effect on the dividend changing or going down or anything like that. So we think there's some good opportunities for improving Ilim. And it goes to that comment I made on my closing statement around making products that are needed in the market, mainly into consumer-oriented end uses, and making them in the right place in the world for your advantage, fiber, cost structure and work force. And this is a perfect example of that.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Chris, I'll just add on. We actually are going to get a dividend payment. I'm looking at my colleagues whose on the -- colleagues who are on the board, as the Ilim joint venture last week approved the dividend payment for 2016. So we'll receive $50 mi
componenttext: And Chris, I'll just add on. We actually are going to get a dividend payment. I'm looking at my colleagues whose on the -- colleagues who are on the board, as the Ilim joint venture last week approved the dividend payment for 2016. So we'll receive $50 million -- between $50 million, $55 million this year. And another recommitment to the dividend flow out of the business given that it's generating significant cash. And also if look at their debt balance, their debt has actually come down as well. So the financial condition of that business is great, and we're counting on dividend out of that business as part of the value-creation equation for International Paper.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and the second quarter is always a better operations quarter than the first. It's not as cold, we just have a lot behind you. It's generally a good operational quarter for lots of reasons, and we anticipate that to happen.
componenttext: Yes, and the second quarter is always a better operations quarter than the first. It's not as cold, we just have a lot behind you. It's generally a good operational quarter for lots of reasons, and we anticipate that to happen.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up. You mentioned, I think this is very [indiscernible] given the opportunity in Madrid. And you say you have a lot of exposure in the fruit, vegetable area. My understanding is that most or all of the fruits and vegetables
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up. You mentioned, I think this is very [indiscernible] given the opportunity in Madrid. And you say you have a lot of exposure in the fruit, vegetable area. My understanding is that most or all of the fruits and vegetables need to be packaged in virgin based kraftliner because of the condensation issue. And has technology changed to allow certain types of recycled board to be introduced there? Is there any kind of a change that has taken place or is taking place? And then is that in part behind your move in Madrid?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, the move in Madrid is really to complement what we do with kraftliner. And your assessment is accurate. I mean there's been lots of attempts to make products with mixed substrates in that field. It really -- it really is driven by the supply chain. Th
componenttext: No, the move in Madrid is really to complement what we do with kraftliner. And your assessment is accurate. I mean there's been lots of attempts to make products with mixed substrates in that field. It really -- it really is driven by the supply chain. There are probably some short supply chain different products, but the humidity from the harvest, all the way to the supply chain to the market is what drives the performance characteristics of fresh food packaging for meeting kraftliner or kraft-like performance characteristics. The industrial business, the high-end industrial business that complements the mix in your plant, because obviously agriculture seasonally, and you want to run your plant and run a successful business over the year. That's where the high-performance lightweight recycled comes in. And it allows us to perform better in some of the best industrial segment versus using board that is not high-performance, it's got to use more of it and things of that nature, you end up not being competitive industrial segment that you really wanted to be in.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from the line of Danny Moran of Macquarie.
componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Danny Moran of Macquarie.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to clarify something on your sheet map that you provided in your earnings presentation. Do you anticipate continued higher year-over-year export shipments in 2Q and for the year? And then do you also expect further price erosion to the export
componenttext: I just want to clarify something on your sheet map that you provided in your earnings presentation. Do you anticipate continued higher year-over-year export shipments in 2Q and for the year? And then do you also expect further price erosion to the export markets?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm assuming you're talking about containerboard. Yes, I mean we feel pretty good about the demand signal that we've gotten from the markets. Margins take a hit, demand seems to be holding up, which says to us, there's a need for the type of product that
componenttext: I'm assuming you're talking about containerboard. Yes, I mean we feel pretty good about the demand signal that we've gotten from the markets. Margins take a hit, demand seems to be holding up, which says to us, there's a need for the type of product that we're supplying to the export markets. And we've been a strategic supplier to those markets for a decade. So we have long-term relationships that we stick with quarter-to-quarter, year in, year out. We feel pretty good about our backlogs for the second quarter. The market is very competitive. I don't want to forecast price, but I just believe that it's competitive. And the types of erosion that we've seen probably continue into the quarter. So we'll manage it accordingly. But we still make decent money on export, and we like it a lot on average through the cycle.

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful, thanks. With all the moving parts in your North American Industrial Packaging business with economic downtime and some capacity creep, on a net basis, do you expect to produce more or less boxes this year?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful, thanks. With all the moving parts in your North American Industrial Packaging business with economic downtime and some capacity creep, on a net basis, do you expect to produce more or less boxes this year?

headline: International Paper Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not going to forecast what we're going to produce. We've said that, over time, our goal is that we position ourselves with the right segments and with the right customers, and we'd expect to perform in line with market as our choices around cust
componenttext: Well, I'm not going to forecast what we're going to produce. We've said that, over time, our goal is that we position ourselves with the right segments and with the right customers, and we'd expect to perform in line with market as our choices around customer mix grew over time. And we've seen a little bit of both here over the past year. Last year, we were under performing because of some of that exposure. And in the first quarter of this year, we were right on top of it. So to us, it's about customer choices and how we align ourselves on the right spot.
