headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Shallan, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Paper Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to tu
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Shallan, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Paper Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jay Royalty, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you, everyone, for joining International Paper's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Our key speakers this morning are Mark Sutton, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Carol Roberts, Senior Vice President
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you, everyone, for joining International Paper's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Our key speakers this morning are Mark Sutton, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Carol Roberts, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are outlined on Slide 2 of our presentation. We will also present certain non-U.S. GAAP financial information. A reconciliation of those figures to U.S. GAAP financial measures are available on our website. Our website also contains copies of the second quarter 2016 earnings press release and today's presentation slides. 
Lastly, relative to the Ilim JV, Slide 4 provides context around the joint venture's financial information and statistical measures. 
With that, I will now turn the call over to Mark Sutton.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jay, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call, and thank you for your interest in International Paper. I'm going to start on Slide 5. International Paper delivered a strong second quarter with solid contribution from our ke
componenttext:
Thanks, Jay, and good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call, and thank you for your interest in International Paper. 
I'm going to start on Slide 5. International Paper delivered a strong second quarter with solid contribution from our key businesses across our enterprise, resulting in an EBITDA margin of 17.6%, which is 50 basis points higher than the second quarter of 2015. Free cash flow for the quarter was strong at $527 million, operations performed well and a heavy quarter of maintenance outages was executed very effectively. The recently converted machine at the Riegelwood mill is running well and on schedule with our expectations. 
On the portfolio front, we completed the sale of the Asia box business and closed on the purchase of the Madrid mill. We have an agreement with Holmen to produce newsprint, which enables sell until we start the recycled containerboard conversion in mid-2017. We expect the converted mill to be up and running in the fourth quarter of 2017. 
And in early May, we announced that we reached an agreement with Weyerhaeuser to buy their pulp business, and we expect to close on that transaction in the fourth quarter. I'm pleased to report that we successfully completed the lump-sum buyout program for our term vested employees in the IP pension plan, which we initiated to further derisk the plan consistent with our balance sheet strategy. 
Finally, the Ilim joint venture delivered another solid quarter performance, and International Paper received a $58 million dividend in the quarter. 
Turning to Slide 6 and speaking a little more specifically to the financial results for the quarter. Revenue was down year-over-year primarily due to the sale of the Sun joint venture in China and the sale of our Carolina brand of coated bristols last year. EPS of $0.92 represented strong performance coming off a solid first quarter. And as you can see in the chart on the right, return on invested capital for the first half of 2016 was solidly above our cost of capital at 10.6%. This is an important metric that we watch very closely because it's a good indicator of whether IP is creating value for our shareholders over time. When we run our businesses well and when we deploy capital I a value-creating way, we see this metric improve. We've had 6 consecutive years above our cost of capital, and we've been on an upward improvement trend for several years. 
All in all, I'm pleased with our performance in the quarter and the first half of 2016. And with that introduction, I'm going to turn it over to Carol Roberts to cover the business highlights and the outlook for the third quarter.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning. As Mark mentioned, IP delivered a strong quarter at $0.92 EPS, driven by seasonally stronger volume and good operational performance. Prices were lower as expected, and I'll put some color on this as we get to the various b
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good morning. As Mark mentioned, IP delivered a strong quarter at $0.92 EPS, driven by seasonally stronger volume and good operational performance. Prices were lower as expected, and I'll put some color on this as we get to the various business segments. We successfully executed a heavy outage quarter that was slightly lower than the first quarter due to less down time from the mill conversion project at Riegelwood. And results for the Ilim JV were slightly lower than the first quarter, mainly due to planned maintenance outages in the quarter and some modest cost inflation. 
Turning to the businesses, and beginning with Industrial Packaging. The business had another strong quarter driven by seasonally stronger volume, good operational performance and some benefits from input cost. These were partially offset by lower containerboard export prices and lower box prices due to the impact of the January containerboard index change, contract renewals and a slightly favorable less favorable mix. Maintenance outage expenses were higher as well. The North American system took 85,000 tons of economic downtime in the quarter to match our supply with our demand. 
Turning to Slide 9, I want to highlight some of the key levers we have within IP's North American Industrial Packaging business that enable us to build upon what is already a great business and make it even better. 
Our sales teams and designers are working with our customers every day to redesign packaging, leverage innovation and find ways to take cost out. IP has a low cost, world-class mill system, along with a vast box and specialty plant footprint with a diverse range of capabilities. And that footprint serves thousands of customers across every consumer segment. 
We're always working to improve our portfolio business and grow with the highest value customers. And we have a portfolio of customers and products second to none in the industry. 
On the manufacturing and supply chain front, our teams are using the most advanced tools and techniques to drive efficiency improvement and cost reduction. And this, of course, positively impacts our margin. 
As Mark mentioned, we're committed to a disciplined and targeted capital investment program in the right places to maintain and improve this world-class systems. 
For example, over the last few years, we have implemented a couple hundred million dollars of cost-reduction projects in the areas of consumption reduction that have IRRs greater than 25%. We continue to have a robust pipeline of these types of opportunities across our broad networks. 
As I said, lots of levers that have contributed to our success, and we'll continue to do so as we move forward. 
Slide 10, moving now to Consumer Packaging. The business experienced a much improved quarter driven by good operations, effective cost management and the lack of maintenance outages. Prices were slightly lower on folding carton and plate stock, but this was fully offset by a more favorable mix. 
Within this segment, our foodservice business benefited from increased volume as we move through the summer cold cup season. 
In printing papers, earnings improved due to lower outage cost associated with the Riegelwood mill conversion, partly offset by a less favorable product mix and lower pulp prices. The negative $11 million in the price mix bucket is fully attributable to the less favorable mix associated with the ramp up and qualification of the duly converted machine in Riegelwood. Paper volume was higher in Europe and Brazil, and it's also worth noting that the significantly lower outage expense in pulp was partially offset by higher planned maintenance outage expense across the remaining Paper business. 
Turning now to Ilim. The JV turned in another solid quarter of performance with volumes up almost 5% year-over-year. The JV had planned maintenance outages at 2 of the mills, which negatively impacted earnings. FX was generally stable throughout the quarter. And as Mark mentioned, IP received a dividend of $58 million during the quarter. The outlook for IP equity earnings for the third quarter is generally in line with the quarter just completed, but I would note that there was a positive gain of $0.01 on FX related to the JVs U.S.-denominated debt in the second quarter that we assume will not repeat in the third quarter. 
Turning to Slide 13. Before I move on to the outlook, I'd like to give an update on actions we've taken or are planning to take around continued prudent management of IP's pension plan. As we previously disclosed in the first quarter 10-Q, we offered a voluntary pension buyout for term-vested former employees. We completed the program and made the associated payments in the second quarter. We paid a total of $1.2 billion to approximately 25,000 former employees out of plan assets, settling the corresponding liability in keeping with our strategy to take risk off the table. A requirement of settling a liability of this magnitude resulted in IP taking a noncash settlement charge of $439 million or $270 million after tax for unamortized actuarial losses, which impacted our non-operating pension expense for the quarter. 
Additionally, we elected to make a voluntary contribution of $250 million to the plan in the second quarter, and we plan to make additional contributions of $500 million by the end of the year. 
Based on our analysis, we believe these contributions make good sense in light of the tax benefits as well as the fee savings and is consistent with our strategy of derisking the plan over time and managing our balance sheet. 
So on Slide 14, moving to the third quarter outlook. Volume is expected to be mostly stable across the businesses, with the exception of EMEA Packaging, which will be lower due to normal seasonality in Morocco. Price for the quarter is expected to be lower in North American Industrial Packaging due to the flow-through effect of the January PPW FX change. This will negatively affect earnings by about $10 million. To a slightly lesser extent, earnings are expected to also be impacted by a less favorable mix in the pulp business as the majority of the tons coming off the new capacity at Riegelwood during ramp-up will be market softwood rolls. All other pricing should be largely stable. 
Operations are expected to continue to perform well, and input cost, particularly energy and OCC in North America, are expected to be higher in the third quarter by roughly $35 million. Maintenance outage expenses are forecasted to be lower by about $60 million. IP equity earnings from the Ilim JV are expected to be relatively flat assuming a stable FX. With this assumption, there will be a nonrepeat of the favorable $0.01 gain from FX on the JV's U.S.-denominated debt in the prior quarter. And as you can see, there are a few other minor items noted on the chart. I would also note that several of the trends we are seeing as we move into the third quarter, such as input cost, are likely to impact the fourth quarter as well. 
So with that, let me turn it back over to Mark.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Carol. So before I wrap things up, I want to take a moment to touch on the strategic opportunity we announced during the quarter that IP has reached an agreement to acquire the assets of Weyerhaeuser's pulp business. When we complete the transac
componenttext:
Thanks, Carol. So before I wrap things up, I want to take a moment to touch on the strategic opportunity we announced during the quarter that IP has reached an agreement to acquire the assets of Weyerhaeuser's pulp business. 
When we complete the transaction, International Paper will be a premier global producer of fluff pulp with a strong position in North America and the ability to serve growing global markets. This strategic combination will also provide us with a talented team and superior research and development capabilities, including a valuable patent portfolio that will enable IP to better serve customers and make our combined businesses more competitive and more profitable. 
The valuation around the acquisition is very compelling and offers an attractive all-in multiple, along with solid double-digit financial returns through real and significant synergies and low integration risk. 
Again, we're very pleased with this acquisition and the integration opportunity ahead of us, and look forward to strengthening this business and the rest of International Paper. 
Moving to Slide 16, I want to briefly come back to the bigger picture for International Paper as we've evolved over the last 18 months or so. Our strategy is to produce fiber-based packaging, pulp and paper where we have advantage production positions and we serve advantaged markets. When we choose the right products, make them in the right places and serve the right markets and the right customers, and when we execute very effectively, we generate the greatest value for customers and our shareholders. 
Looking at that recent decisions we've made, I believe our actions in Asia, the improvement in our North American Industrial Packaging business, the investment in European packaging and the opportunity with our Riegelwood mill conversion and the purchase of Weyerhaeuser's fluff pulp business are consistent with this strategy. 
So in closing, I'm encouraged by how International Paper continues to consistently perform in a challenging and changing global environment. Our focus is squarely on execution from working closely with our customers to deliver superior value, to running and improving our operations, to driving cost out of our system and supply chain, all to maintain and improve margins as you've seen IP do over the last several years. Our financial discipline is evident from our constant vigilance to maintain a strong balance sheet to the Riegelwood capital allocation. We're committed to strengthening our portfolio businesses and to increase the value of the company and ensure an attractive future for IP and our shareholders. And finally, we remain intensely focused on strong free cash flow generation and delivering returns well above our cost of capital to drive shareholder value. 
With that, I'd like to turn it back over to the operator and open the lines for questions.

componenttext: Well, at the -- what we're not going to do is really forecast on pricing. As we shared with you in the last call, this is going to be more or less a second half event. We will -- we do expect to see prices to move as we kind of move forward. Where we settle out in the fourth quarter, there's still a fair amount of water under the bridge to pass, so let's stay tuned for that as we report out in -- for the fourth quarter, okay?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, it's Tim. Market conditions, so far, I think, roughly in line with what we expected. Through the first half of the year on box, a little bit uneven from month-to-month. But overall, pretty much what we expected. And I think, we continue to look at 1
componenttext: Mark, it's Tim. Market conditions, so far, I think, roughly in line with what we expected. Through the first half of the year on box, a little bit uneven from month-to-month. But overall, pretty much what we expected. And I think, we continue to look at 1% to 1.5% growth for the full year. So I think kind of in line with how we were thinking about it. On the export side, demand continues to be good for craft liner. Markets seemed like they started firm as we went through the second quarter, so we'll have to see how that plays out. But on balance, it's feels, as expected, and pretty stable.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Staphos from Bank of America.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on the progress on the quarter. I have a couple of questions, maybe, first, segueing a little bit off of Mark's question. So should we assume that if the outlook is 1% to 1.5% in growth for industrial, that's what you've been seeing early
componenttext: Congratulations on the progress on the quarter. I have a couple of questions, maybe, first, segueing a little bit off of Mark's question. So should we assume that if the outlook is 1% to 1.5% in growth for industrial, that's what you've been seeing early in the third quarter, Tim? And have you seen any kind of effect at all from Brexit in terms of customer expectations in Europe or even relative to the U.S? Again it would appear that we haven't, but I just wanted to ask about for the record.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, George. Yes, I mean, so far, in the third quarter, it looks like it's pulling up pretty much as we expected. In terms of Brexit, I'll just speak for containerboard because there's a whole European business apart from what we do here in North
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, George. Yes, I mean, so far, in the third quarter, it looks like it's pulling up pretty much as we expected. In terms of Brexit, I'll just speak for containerboard because there's a whole European business apart from what we do here in North America. But we have a very small position in the U.K. So from a containerboard export standpoint, we don't expect any kind of significant impact at all.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And George, this is Mark. For the company, as a whole, the first order effect is the Brexit action is pretty minor given our market positions there. We really don't make any products in the U.K. We do serve the market. Second order, I think, everybody is
componenttext: And George, this is Mark. For the company, as a whole, the first order effect is the Brexit action is pretty minor given our market positions there. We really don't make any products in the U.K. We do serve the market. Second order, I think, everybody is still trying to figure that out.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks. My question is probably more on the second order than the first order, but  I understand why there'll be a little bit of lack of clarity at this juncture. 2 other questions, and I'll turn it over. Carol, can you talk a little bit -- or Tim, c
componenttext: Yes, thanks. My question is probably more on the second order than the first order, but  I understand why there'll be a little bit of lack of clarity at this juncture. 2 other questions, and I'll turn it over. Carol, can you talk a little bit -- or Tim, can you talk a little bit about what additional cost reduction opportunities you might have, what other leverage you might have to optimizing the mills? I think the number that's been cited in the past and again on this call is around $200 million. And as you ultimately achieve that, as you look at another couple of years, does it get harder to get increased in improvement -- performance improvement at that level given that you're already so low on the cost curve? So that's question #1. And then question #2, just a quickie. Can you update us at all on any things to be mindful of in terms of the progress and the process with the Weyerhaeuser closing?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll just take the first part and then Carol can jump in. So I'll take the first part of the question around cost optimization. We feel like it's a pretty rich environment. When you've got such a large system, we move, on average, 200,000 tons a week f
componenttext: So I'll just take the first part and then Carol can jump in. So I'll take the first part of the question around cost optimization. We feel like it's a pretty rich environment. When you've got such a large system, we move, on average, 200,000 tons a week from our mills to our box plant. So a lot of productive capacity, a lot of supply chain, we got people working in all of these phases looking for value creation, waste elimination-type opportunity. So is it easy? No, it's not easy. We work pretty hard at it, but I think it's pretty rich environment for us.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: George, on Weyerhaeuser, as you know, we're going through the regulatory approval process. We've done this a couple of times in the recent past, and our experience with say things are going as you would expect them to go. We still expect to close in the f
componenttext: George, on Weyerhaeuser, as you know, we're going through the regulatory approval process. We've done this a couple of times in the recent past, and our experience with say things are going as you would expect them to go. We still expect to close in the fourth quarter.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari from Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari from Citi.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Year-to-date, we've seen really large number of acquisitions of independent box plants by some of your competitors. And I was wondering if you could just talk maybe generally about how that's changed the commercial environment or if it's changed the comme
componenttext: Year-to-date, we've seen really large number of acquisitions of independent box plants by some of your competitors. And I was wondering if you could just talk maybe generally about how that's changed the commercial environment or if it's changed the commercial environment? Or has it impacted the tons you sell into the open market, or if you had to shift your board sales around? I was wondering if you could just speak to that. And then in terms of your own integration rate, can you remind us, do you have a target integrated rates or a preferred method for growing an integration rate or any thoughts you could share will be helpful.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start with the last and work backwards. On integration, we don't have a target. What we want to do is pick the right segments, pick the right customers, and where we can deliver value proposition, take great positions and then grow with those
componenttext: Yes, let me start with the last and work backwards. On integration, we don't have a target. What we want to do is pick the right segments, pick the right customers, and where we can deliver value proposition, take great positions and then grow with those customers over time. And then it will be what it will be. We like our integrated channel. We like it here in North America. We also like it in other parts of the world where we ship more to our converting businesses there. But we also like the 2 other channels that we participate in. In terms of the acquisitions, it hasn't impacted us directly. We haven't had to make any types of shifts, and I don't think, from my standpoint, it's one opinion, but I don't think I see it had any material impact on the size of the independent market or it's very fragmented. There's a lot of players in that space. So we haven't seen any direct impact cost by acquisitions over the past few years at this point.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's really helpful. And then just a follow-up. You do have a decent size presence in Turkey. Given the events there, have you seen any disruption to your shipments or your people there? And are you taking any steps to manage risk into the second
componenttext: Okay, that's really helpful. And then just a follow-up. You do have a decent size presence in Turkey. Given the events there, have you seen any disruption to your shipments or your people there? And are you taking any steps to manage risk into the second half?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question. And then so specifically, to the events of the past couple of weeks. No, we have not seen any major impact. I think you look at that region in the world, and Turkey, because of where it's located approximate to some of the unr
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question. And then so specifically, to the events of the past couple of weeks. No, we have not seen any major impact. I think you look at that region in the world, and Turkey, because of where it's located approximate to some of the unrest, we've seen demand economy underperform and some diminishment of demand. But overall, it's a very good market for us. We believe in it long term. And we manage day-to-day to balance out the risk that we have. But no, we still got a sizable presence in there and like it very much.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon from Vertical Research.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Chip Dillon from Vertical Research.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question I have is, first one, is on the maintenance situation. It looks like you guys are, I guess, doing better than you thought we would. If I go back about 6 months, it looks like your expense was scheduled to be around $534 million for the year, and
componenttext: Question I have is, first one, is on the maintenance situation. It looks like you guys are, I guess, doing better than you thought we would. If I go back about 6 months, it looks like your expense was scheduled to be around $534 million for the year, and then in April, that fell to $508 million, now it stand at $462 million for the year. And I didn't know if that was more a function of deferring or were you finding better ways to do what you normally do?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chip, this is Carol and I'll take a shot at that. I think it's both. I think we always look to find better and smarter ways to execute outages. I think we're also making choices about what work. Do we need to do? Do we have some headwinds against our expe
componenttext: Chip, this is Carol and I'll take a shot at that. I think it's both. I think we always look to find better and smarter ways to execute outages. I think we're also making choices about what work. Do we need to do? Do we have some headwinds against our expectations for the year? And so Mark's challenged the organization pretty hard about what are some options we have. And then we got a very large global footprint. So 1 mill -- we don't break it out at that level of detail, but there is some work that we've been able to push into the next year with extending outage cycle. So it's all of the above. And the main story here is it continues to be an important part of the work we do, vital to running well, but we're going to spend our dollars very, very wisely. And so I think that's what you're seeing. And we'll try to continue to provide the transparency such that you could see how that evolves through time.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chip, I'd just add on top of that. It is a strategy for us to get better in this area. And so each year, we deploy more predictive tools than we did the year before, and that leads us to making different decisions in where we spend the money and what we h
componenttext: Chip, I'd just add on top of that. It is a strategy for us to get better in this area. And so each year, we deploy more predictive tools than we did the year before, and that leads us to making different decisions in where we spend the money and what we have to repair versus what we thought we had to repair. And we'll continue to get better at that. There's a lot of technology and techniques, precision, maintenance techniques and predictive tools that help you work on just needs to be worked on. And we're getting better at that every year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, good. And one other question is, when I look at the balance sheet, the pension number has risen from about $3.5 billion to a little over $4 billion, and I would assume that includes the impact of what you just settled and the $250 million. And so I
componenttext: Okay, good. And one other question is, when I look at the balance sheet, the pension number has risen from about $3.5 billion to a little over $4 billion, and I would assume that includes the impact of what you just settled and the $250 million. And so I guess my question is, when we include the $500 million you're going to put in, in the second half and if we would assume rates stay about where they are, will that be a fair sort of number to see on the balance sheet or close to a fair number we should expect to see at year-end, again, assuming no change in rates from here?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chip. And the one clarification, which I think I stated, but if I didn't want to be clear. With this program that we did, it did require a remeasurement of the plan, which normally we wouldn't be doing at the end of June. We would remeasure the plan
componenttext: Yes, Chip. And the one clarification, which I think I stated, but if I didn't want to be clear. With this program that we did, it did require a remeasurement of the plan, which normally we wouldn't be doing at the end of June. We would remeasure the plan at the end of the year. So the liability that shows on the balance sheet has been impacted by the very low interest rates that hit at the end of the June, which was a combination of all kinds of things going on the globe. So a couple of things will happen. One is we'll have a half a year of asset performance, we'll have the contributions that go in and we'll also remeasure the plan depending upon how interest rates will from June 30 for International Paper to the end of the year. So yes, you're thinking about it correct.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Debbie Jones from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Debbie Jones from Deutsche Bank.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A call earlier this week, I think one of your competitors was asked about the ability to get permitting for kraft mill capacity in the U.S. and suggested they didn't think it was really possible or more difficult. I was wondering if you could just give us
componenttext: A call earlier this week, I think one of your competitors was asked about the ability to get permitting for kraft mill capacity in the U.S. and suggested they didn't think it was really possible or more difficult. I was wondering if you could just give us your thoughts on that because I think it's important, not only for the fluff pulp business, but also longer-term kraft containerboard mill assets in the U.S. I think the conventional wisdom has been that, that wasn't possible.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Debbie, I think, we haven't tried to permit a new pulp mill in a while in the U.S. so we can't speak from actual experience recently. But we think just based on some of the things we know about the existing mills and the way that you have to operate wood
componenttext: Debbie, I think, we haven't tried to permit a new pulp mill in a while in the U.S. so we can't speak from actual experience recently. But we think just based on some of the things we know about the existing mills and the way that you have to operate wood pulping operations, it's a pretty difficult process to imagine happening.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. And then my follow-up question, just -- we haven't talked about G&A or CapEx that much on the call. Is the $1.3 billion still a good number for the year for each?
componenttext: Okay, thank you. And then my follow-up question, just -- we haven't talked about G&A or CapEx that much on the call. Is the $1.3 billion still a good number for the year for each?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Debbie, this is Carol. I think the numbers are probably trending closer to 1.25, and that's a combination of a couple of things. One is, we're on unit of operations, and so as we've ran our North American containerboard systems, with people you can see ou
componenttext: Debbie, this is Carol. I think the numbers are probably trending closer to 1.25, and that's a combination of a couple of things. One is, we're on unit of operations, and so as we've ran our North American containerboard systems, with people you can see our utilization of those assets has impacted it. So it's come down a little bit from our original expectations.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Quinn from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paul Quinn from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just question on synergies with the perspective versus Weyerhaeuser's pulp business. Just noting that where sort of got the $28 million in cost savings in 14 47 and 15 [ph] they're targeting 40 to 50 in '16, so that totals 1 20 , and you're expecting 1 75
componenttext: Just question on synergies with the perspective versus Weyerhaeuser's pulp business. Just noting that where sort of got the $28 million in cost savings in 14 47 and 15 [ph] they're targeting 40 to 50 in '16, so that totals 1 20 , and you're expecting 1 75 , so I'm just running where the 1 75  the major buckets are? And is there that much synergies left in the business.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, it's a great question. I think the 1 75  we feel really good about. And it's in the categories that we have demonstrated when you put 2 really good businesses together, you can find it. So some of it's obviously an overhead, but sourcing and how we
componenttext: Paul, it's a great question. I think the 1 75  we feel really good about. And it's in the categories that we have demonstrated when you put 2 really good businesses together, you can find it. So some of it's obviously an overhead, but sourcing and how we buy all the inputs and get synergies there. A big win for this business is supply chain, inbound supply chain, outbound supply chain, and probably, most importantly, making the right products at the right facility. So that your total cost to serve is the lowest and the total manufacturing cost is the lowest. There's other optimization opportunities, but that's really the buckets that will drive the synergies.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman from Rolf Equity Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman from Rolf Equity Research.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just wondering if you could give a little bit of color on fiber cost, both wood and OCC. So your wood cost have been coming down pretty nicely, it seemed to be at a couple year low. Is that a trend you'd expect to continue? And just any thoughts on wh
componenttext: I'm just wondering if you could give a little bit of color on fiber cost, both wood and OCC. So your wood cost have been coming down pretty nicely, it seemed to be at a couple year low. Is that a trend you'd expect to continue? And just any thoughts on what's been driving the recent uptick in OCC? And do you expect that to continue?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gail, this is Carol. I'm going just to comment on the wood, and then I think I'll probably let Tim comment on the OCC. The wood's a combination of effects. It's had been -- I think we would have described it in years past as stubbornly high, which was abo
componenttext: Gail, this is Carol. I'm going just to comment on the wood, and then I think I'll probably let Tim comment on the OCC. The wood's a combination of effects. It's had been -- I think we would have described it in years past as stubbornly high, which was above historic levels for us, and has come down, and that's been a combination of weather, of strategy, of inventories, of a lot of things that are going on, so we're pleased to see that. And we're hoping that the current level wood cost will continue. We've got some concerns about other inputs headwinds and wood, quite honestly, is not one of the ones that we're anticipating. So a pretty good story on wood. And then I'll let Tim comment on the OCC.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I would just say, more of pull from China, which is having some impact. You're seeing prices in China go up over the past couple of months. Maybe because there's a little bit less generation of locally sourced OCC in country. But I think this is
componenttext: Yes, and I would just say, more of pull from China, which is having some impact. You're seeing prices in China go up over the past couple of months. Maybe because there's a little bit less generation of locally sourced OCC in country. But I think this is kind of what we expect a normal type of variation around OCC pricing if we go through the year. It's going to go up, it's going to go down based on generation and usage. Our long-term view is that it will continue to rise over time, but I think this is just a normal seasonal cost of variation that we're experiencing at the moment.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thank you. And just on consumer board. We're, I guess, 4 or 5 months into the start of the [indiscernible] board project. [indiscernible] only a week or 2 into the start of the [indiscernible] mills, but I'm just wondering if you could give some per
componenttext: Okay, thank you. And just on consumer board. We're, I guess, 4 or 5 months into the start of the [indiscernible] board project. [indiscernible] only a week or 2 into the start of the [indiscernible] mills, but I'm just wondering if you could give some perspective, particularly given your position in the European market, how -- where that the board's going and how it's impacting the market, if at all? And any global region?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mike, I can start here. We know that from an import standpoint, that we've seen imports in North America up, let's call it roughly 10% to 12%. That's off of fairly smaller base, so it's amount to about 20,000 tons, and we know that some of that pr
componenttext: This is Mike, I can start here. We know that from an import standpoint, that we've seen imports in North America up, let's call it roughly 10% to 12%. That's off of fairly smaller base, so it's amount to about 20,000 tons, and we know that some of that product is here. We haven't it in an appreciable -- at an appreciable level right now. So from a significant standpoint, at least to this date, nothing significant in North America.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, in the European context, we redesigned our product offering out of our [indiscernible] mill, and it's a real specialty high-end high yield board. And so the customers we have and the segments we play in, we haven't seen any disruption. I do
componenttext: Yes, I think, in the European context, we redesigned our product offering out of our [indiscernible] mill, and it's a real specialty high-end high yield board. And so the customers we have and the segments we play in, we haven't seen any disruption. I do think that board as you mentioned is finding its way into some of market, but not exactly in the spot that we are.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, just on that. Any sense that it's causing repatriation of exports domestically as it finds global markets?
componenttext: Again, just on that. Any sense that it's causing repatriation of exports domestically as it finds global markets?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Direct, I mean, we've seen -- we've certainly seen -- as you see published a drop in exports here in North America, particularly around SBS. But attributing that to a specific event is a little bit -- would be a little bit challenging to do at this stage.
componenttext: Direct, I mean, we've seen -- we've certainly seen -- as you see published a drop in exports here in North America, particularly around SBS. But attributing that to a specific event is a little bit -- would be a little bit challenging to do at this stage.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think we've had a personal experience with our export customers and had made losing a position to that particular product. But I -- could it be happening more broadly? I think we'll figure that out, but we haven't had that exact experience.
componenttext: I don't think we've had a personal experience with our export customers and had made losing a position to that particular product. But I -- could it be happening more broadly? I think we'll figure that out, but we haven't had that exact experience.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Connelly from CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mark Connelly from CLSA.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on consumer, that business has that been cut back with Sun and all that, and it's now at a point where the business looks pretty good and attractive, but the scale is small enough that we're starting to wonder what its significant is. Do
componenttext: First question is on consumer, that business has that been cut back with Sun and all that, and it's now at a point where the business looks pretty good and attractive, but the scale is small enough that we're starting to wonder what its significant is. Do you see enough opportunities to grow that business over the next couple of years, whether it's internal spend or M&A, consistent with the strategy that you've laid out? And if you do, is that going to be more likely in the U.S. or elsewhere?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a good question. Consumer business is still an important business, and you think about that strategic framework around fiber-based packaging, it fits squarely in there, and we have a niche business, there's no doubt, SBS on the board side and one typ
componenttext: It's a good question. Consumer business is still an important business, and you think about that strategic framework around fiber-based packaging, it fits squarely in there, and we have a niche business, there's no doubt, SBS on the board side and one type of converting, but we also have in Europe, a very good also niche high-end FBB business. When you take them all together, our challenge internally is to figure out the ways that we can create value by improving those business and/or growing. But when you put the 2 together and you look at the size of International Paper, they're not insignificant in the size of our company. The ways to improve or the ways we would imagine make more converting, should we offer other substrates, and that's constantly in our strategic evaluation. And I wouldn't necessarily comment on whether we would do more or do less or more in other part of the world. But the U.S. business and the consumer behavior for these type of products is pretty strong.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. Thank you. And second question, I was happy to see that you highlighted the higher value pulps beyond fluff that you're going to have in your portfolio. Those have not gotten a lot of attention. And of course, IP has some histor
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. Thank you. And second question, I was happy to see that you highlighted the higher value pulps beyond fluff that you're going to have in your portfolio. Those have not gotten a lot of attention. And of course, IP has some historical experience there. Is that an opportunity, do you expect to try to expand now that you've got this nicer, deeper portfolio?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the way to create value in a specialty fibers business is obviously to continue to trade up to the higher value whatever to product doing for the customer. And some of those higher value pulps provide a tremendous technical value or service. And s
componenttext: I think the way to create value in a specialty fibers business is obviously to continue to trade up to the higher value whatever to product doing for the customer. And some of those higher value pulps provide a tremendous technical value or service. And so we will have -- and to the question I got on synergies, we will have enough capacity with the 2 systems together to really optimize and make more of those higher value products as the customers that we have need them. So we are excited about that. And we will continue like we do in a number of other businesses, start with the product mix and a customer mix and work to improve that over time with more of the higher value mix in the portfolio than when we started.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Adam Josephson from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Adam Josephson from KeyBanc.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we've made a lot of progress. We were down in the quarter again. And look, we try to run a lean supply chain to begin with. So we're managing it realtime, day-to-day, week-to-week, and we're making adjustments as we need to. As I mentioned earlier
componenttext: I think we've made a lot of progress. We were down in the quarter again. And look, we try to run a lean supply chain to begin with. So we're managing it realtime, day-to-day, week-to-week, and we're making adjustments as we need to. As I mentioned earlier, we moved roughly 200,000 tons a week in board out to our systems. So I think we came in lower in the second quarter. I think we've adjusted to supply chain for the moment. We'll have to see what happens. The thing about the supply chain is it doesn't stay static. If you talk to the rail companies or their parking cars and trying to make adjustments. And so I think we're nimble enough to hopefully, we see those changes coming soon enough and we react ahead of time.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And Carol, just 2 quick ones for you. Just on the EBIT bridge that you talked about. You've got the $60 million lower maintenance, but you have the $35 million-or-so higher input costs and then $15 million-or-so of lower price mix in North America
componenttext: Thanks. And Carol, just 2 quick ones for you. Just on the EBIT bridge that you talked about. You've got the $60 million lower maintenance, but you have the $35 million-or-so higher input costs and then $15 million-or-so of lower price mix in North America. Are those the big buckets that you would point us to, just to be clear?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, Adam. I think those are the big movers in the big buckets. And I think the one for the second half that will be interesting to see how it plays out is going to be those input cost. I mean, clearly, the outages are pretty clear and some of the commentaries we gave around prices things we have the line of sight to. So we'll have to see how the input cost evolve over this second half of the year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. And Carol, just one last one on pension. So after the $500 million of contributions in the second have and given whatever you expect asset returns to be, what do you expect your pension gap to be at year-end? And will these contributions that you'
componenttext: Thanks. And Carol, just one last one on pension. So after the $500 million of contributions in the second have and given whatever you expect asset returns to be, what do you expect your pension gap to be at year-end? And will these contributions that you're making have any impact on your share repurchases?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the pension, I think you can think about the contribution into the pension should definitely contribute toward closing the gap. The big, unknowns will be really discount rates and interest rates, and I've got to think they should only go up from whe
componenttext: So on the pension, I think you can think about the contribution into the pension should definitely contribute toward closing the gap. The big, unknowns will be really discount rates and interest rates, and I've got to think they should only go up from where they were in June 30 and an asset return. So it will be hard to speculate on those things, but clearly, the $500 million should be helpful. And your second part of your question, Adam?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carol, just given the pending acquisition of the fluff pulp business and given the pension contributions you're making, will that have any bearing on your stock repurchases either this year or next year?
componenttext: Carol, just given the pending acquisition of the fluff pulp business and given the pension contributions you're making, will that have any bearing on your stock repurchases either this year or next year?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we remain committed to the buyback. And as we all know, we have probably a little less than $1 billion left. That said, we've always said that if there's opportunities for investments into the business to create value, that those will be important
componenttext: Yes. So we remain committed to the buyback. And as we all know, we have probably a little less than $1 billion left. That said, we've always said that if there's opportunities for investments into the business to create value, that those will be important priorities. And with the size and scale of the Weyerhaeuser pulp acquisition, getting the funds to take care of that and then addressing our debt profile would probably be our highest priority in the next year or so. So then you could draw a conclusion about what does that mean for the buyback? I think it will depend very much on how things progress, the business conditions we see. I feel very good about our ability to continue to generate very strong free cash flow. So we'll have to see how that manifests and unfolds over the next 12 to 24 months.

componenttext: Great. Thanks for that. And then secondly, I saw a -- it was kind of a weird press release from the FERC indicating that you have regulatory approval from the Weyerhaeuser assets. So a, I don't even know if that's real. But if it is, is that kind of a good press for the DOJ process?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. We have gotten that approval, but that's a different process than the DOJ process. It's one, when we say we're under regulatory approval, that's one of the regulatory approvals. Everybody focuses on the DOJ
componenttext: That's the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. We have gotten that approval, but that's a different process than the DOJ process. It's one, when we say we're under regulatory approval, that's one of the regulatory approvals. Everybody focuses on the DOJ, but there are more than just the Department of Justice.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, I wondered, it started off, if we could talk a little bit about what you're doing on both sides of the business down in Brazil right now to improve performance?
componenttext: Mark, I wondered, it started off, if we could talk a little bit about what you're doing on both sides of the business down in Brazil right now to improve performance?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Mark, on the -- I'll start on the packaging side, which is the business that's challenged because of its exposure to the Brazil economy. As I said, the last couple of calls, what we're trying to do with that business is improve it from a cost profile s
componenttext: So Mark, on the -- I'll start on the packaging side, which is the business that's challenged because of its exposure to the Brazil economy. As I said, the last couple of calls, what we're trying to do with that business is improve it from a cost profile standpoint. Redesigning the way we're organized from people standpoint and redesigning the way that we make and supply the containerboard to our box plants. And then be as strong as we can and perform where we think we can perform in a positive economy versus a minus 4%. That business has the potential to perform much better at a plus 4%, and being able to cover inflation with some degree of pricing versus a minus 4% market and being behind the inflation. So what we're trying to do is change the cost structure, make sure we continue to focus on the customers we have, even though everybody in almost every segment is hurting right now and be well positioned when Brazil's economy begins to pick up. That's what we can control, and we're being very careful with any investments and really trying to do what I would say is fundamental basic blocking and tackling on the commercial side and on the operational side. On the Paper business, we continue to perform very well in that business. Part of it is because it fits squarely into being if you're going to make uncoated free sheet and be a global provider, that is the place to make it. And it starts with the fiber cost structure and our fiber available. So given our export position and given the fact that paper market in Brazil hasn't been hit as much as some of the consumer products market that hit the box business, we're continuing to perform well. And this is part of the same story is getting our cost even lower and making sure that we go out the extra mile to take care of our customers, both in Brazil and outside of Brazil. And we still have some of the strongest EBITDA margins in all of IP in our Brazil Paper business.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if you take the recent past, we've been in the mid-30s on several quarterly reports. And if you look at the FX impact, that's occurred over the last couple of quarters, if you just kind of strip that out, which you can't, but if you did, you
componenttext: Well, I think if you take the recent past, we've been in the mid-30s on several quarterly reports. And if you look at the FX impact, that's occurred over the last couple of quarters, if you just kind of strip that out, which you can't, but if you did, you're back into the low-30s. So it's a 30-plus percent EBITDA margin business over time.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. Then I just have a follow on for Tim Nicholls. Tim, you've taken a little over 600,000 tons of economic downtime in containerboard in the last 4 quarters. Should we think about IP going forward as just being willing to carry kind of that
componenttext: Okay. All right. Then I just have a follow on for Tim Nicholls. Tim, you've taken a little over 600,000 tons of economic downtime in containerboard in the last 4 quarters. Should we think about IP going forward as just being willing to carry kind of that much flex in the system?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, good question, Mark. I don't want to quantify and say it's going to be X number of tons, but there is going to be some amount of system flags that we actually need. We're managing a system that is huge. And just normal seasonality, the way we run our
componenttext: Yes, good question, Mark. I don't want to quantify and say it's going to be X number of tons, but there is going to be some amount of system flags that we actually need. We're managing a system that is huge. And just normal seasonality, the way we run our supply chain and the way we try to service customers and our businesses, we believe that we're better off flexing over time than trying to cover it with positioning inventory. You always get it wrong. So yes, we'll have some amount of downtime every year as we go through the year just balancing out.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Gaffner from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Gaffner from Barclays.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Carol, just another question on the pension and I hate to harp on it, but the issues is that, if you look at the last 3 years, you had to put $1.8 billion of cash into the pension, which is -- looks like about 1/3 of the free cash flow over the period. So
componenttext: Carol, just another question on the pension and I hate to harp on it, but the issues is that, if you look at the last 3 years, you had to put $1.8 billion of cash into the pension, which is -- looks like about 1/3 of the free cash flow over the period. So I guess, as we move into 2017, I mean, really based on the interest rates today, do you plan any more cash contribution over the next 3 years, let's say?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scott. And just a qualifier on what you said is that the contributions we made, while real, were essentially voluntary. Voluntary, meaning, as we look at our balance sheet, and we think about where to take the cash to manage our debt, we've looked at
componenttext: Yes, Scott. And just a qualifier on what you said is that the contributions we made, while real, were essentially voluntary. Voluntary, meaning, as we look at our balance sheet, and we think about where to take the cash to manage our debt, we've looked at the economics around the pension and said, "That's not a bad place to go with some excess cash right now." Part of it's the tax advantaged way of doing this. The other thing we always consider is we're always looking out and thinking about, will we have a regret factor long term. And we never want to have too much where we put money and then say, "Geez, why did we do that?" So it's a balancing act based upon option. So I think what you'll see us do is right now, this is what makes sense for us given the point we are relative to our overall debt profile, and there will be no required contribution out until 19 [ph], and even 19 [ph] is pretty small number. So that gives us choices, and we'll continue to make the choices around all those variables that we think meets our needs the best.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is the comment on no cash contribution until 2019 based on the year end 2015 discount rates and expected rates of return? Or is it based on today's -- on the revaluation you were talking about?
componenttext: Okay. And is the comment on no cash contribution until 2019 based on the year end 2015 discount rates and expected rates of return? Or is it based on today's -- on the revaluation you were talking about?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, remember, there's 2 ways you have to look at your pension. There's one for accounting, and that's your pension benefits obligation, that's the balance sheet. And then there's the funding. The funding is impacted by other factor, considering just the
componenttext: Well, remember, there's 2 ways you have to look at your pension. There's one for accounting, and that's your pension benefits obligation, that's the balance sheet. And then there's the funding. The funding is impacted by other factor, considering just the policy out of Washington. Remember, we talked a couple of years ago about [indiscernible] and how that was the acronyms for the smoothing of interest rates. So we have very good line of sight on the required contributions based upon those things, and they're smoothed out. So we know pretty certainly where that is. Now what we don't know is that, that accounting piece that hits at the end of the year, which comes from discount rate. Remember, 100 basis points for us is about a $1.5 billion to $1.6 billion delta in that liability.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Mark, if I look at return on invested capital year-to-date, 10.6%, which is in line with the first half of last year, and for the full year 2015, you had the record 11% return on invested capital. So is there anything in the second half? I
componenttext: Okay. And then Mark, if I look at return on invested capital year-to-date, 10.6%, which is in line with the first half of last year, and for the full year 2015, you had the record 11% return on invested capital. So is there anything in the second half? I mean, and you hit those numbers despite some headwinds in the first half of the year, is there anything in the second half that would preclude you from getting back to that 11% return on invested capital in 2016?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the one new thing we have is the Weyerhaeuser acquisition, which we think will close in the fourth quarter. And that will have a temporary effect as we bring that debt on, and then we'll see it go back up. But what's important, Scott, is we
componenttext: Well, I think the one new thing we have is the Weyerhaeuser acquisition, which we think will close in the fourth quarter. And that will have a temporary effect as we bring that debt on, and then we'll see it go back up. But what's important, Scott, is we think about the return on invested capital over a long period of time, and we think about it in bands. So the first band is get it to your cost of capital. We've demonstrated we can do that. And then we look at -- 2, as I mentioned report, 200 or 300 basis points above our cost of capital and finding a way to settle in that band. And then the question is always, do you create more value by making your enterprise a larger enterprise at that return? Or do you create more value by raising that return even further? And there is analytical approaches to that -- that backup the solid business case. And so the point number is sort of a blood pressure check. But over time, we want to be in that zone where we have a couple of hundred or more basis points between our 8% cost of capital and our actual returns.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Manuel from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Manuel from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I kind of wanted to come back to some of the Weyerhaeuser assets and the fluff pulp and some of the different pieces there. Once you put this all together, can you talk about your ability to kind of flex between making fluff pulp when you want to but some
componenttext: I kind of wanted to come back to some of the Weyerhaeuser assets and the fluff pulp and some of the different pieces there. Once you put this all together, can you talk about your ability to kind of flex between making fluff pulp when you want to but some of the other grades, whether it's SBS, word, et cetera, what do you kind of view? I think we all know what kind of long-term demand looks for fluff, but perhaps maybe what some of the other end markets are, what you think long-term demand looks like there and your ability to sort of toggle back and forth?

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Chris, we haven't been able to do any detailed integration work. But when you look at our system and we look at what we can publicly get available on the assets and the products that Weyerhaeuser's making, we will have, as I mentioned early, enough
componenttext: Well, Chris, we haven't been able to do any detailed integration work. But when you look at our system and we look at what we can publicly get available on the assets and the products that Weyerhaeuser's making, we will have, as I mentioned early, enough capacity to really optimize the production. But the real focus in this business for us the higher value add at specialty fibers, starting with fluff and moving up. The rest of the pulp's important, and you'll always have to make some of it as you make transitions, and we have really good customers for that pulp. But the focus is really from fluff, basic fluff, all the way up to the high value-added specialty fibers. And we will have, on day 1 when these business come together, because we've invested in the business recently and Weyerhaeuser's invested in the business, but we will have the capacity we need to make the products we want to make for the foreseeable future.

headline: International Paper Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
