componenttext: Good morning. My name is Sarah, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the International Paper Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I will now like to turn it over to Mr. Jay Royalty, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thanks, everyone, for joining International Paper's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Our key speakers this morning are Mark Sutton, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Carol Roberts, Senior Vice President and
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thanks, everyone, for joining International Paper's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Our key speakers this morning are Mark Sutton, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Carol Roberts, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties, which are outlined on Slide 2 of our presentation. We will also present certain non-U.S. GAAP financial information. A reconciliation of those figures to U.S. GAAP financial measures are available on our website. Our website also contains copies of the third quarter 2016 earnings press release and today's presentation slides. 
Lastly, relative to the Ilim JV, Slide 4 provides context around the joint venture's financial information and statistical measures. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mark Sutton.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jay, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us this morning to review our third quarter results and our fourth quarter outlook. I'm going to start on Slide 5. International Paper delivered an overall solid performance in the third qua
componenttext:
Thanks, Jay, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us this morning to review our third quarter results and our fourth quarter outlook. I'm going to start on Slide 5. 
International Paper delivered an overall solid performance in the third quarter, beginning with strong free cash flow of $575 million. Results in our North American Industrial Packaging business were significantly affected by rising input costs, which negatively impacted earnings by $36 million quarter-over-quarter, along with a slightly less favorable mix and modest price erosion which squeezed our margins a bit. We announced, and are in the process of implementing, a domestic containerboard price increase, as well as a corresponding U.S. box price increase. 
We continue to see improved the market demand across both our North American box business and our global pulp business. We experienced strong operational performances across our North American, EMEA and Brazil papers business as well as continuing strong performance in our Ilim joint venture in Russia. Also during the quarter, our Board of Directors approved a 5% increase to our annual dividend in our October meeting moving it to a $1.85 per share. This marks the fifth consecutive year of a dividend increase since we established our dividend policy in 2012 when the dividend was $1.05 per share. This reinforces our confidence in the strength and sustainability of our free cash flow and our commitment to return a meaningful portion of our cash generation to our shareholders. 
Relative to the portfolio, we continue to actively work toward being prepared to close the acquisition of Weyerhaeuser's pulp business in the fourth quarter. We received the European Union's approval last week and we received Brazil's approval just this week, but we still await a few others that we hope to receive shortly. Also we've made the [ph] decision not to pursue a potential expansion into containerboard in India, and as a consequence, we wrote off a modest investment we had made in land and engineering for our potential site. 
Continuing with our financial results on Slide 6. You can see the various key metrics in the table on the slide and I'll remind you of just a couple of points. The year-over-year revenue decline is primarily due to the divestitures of our Sun joint venture and our box business in China as well as the sale of our coated bristols business in North America. As you can see on the slide, IP continues to deliver strong margins in varying economic conditions at 17.6% for the third quarter. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Carol and return at the end to wrap up and move it to question and answers. Thank you. Carol?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. Taking a look at the bridge from the second to third quarter, you can see that our EPS performance was generally flat. As Mark mentioned, we encountered meaningful input cost inflation in the quarter primarily on
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good morning, everyone. Taking a look at the bridge from the second to third quarter, you can see that our EPS performance was generally flat. As Mark mentioned, we encountered meaningful input cost inflation in the quarter primarily on OCC and natural gas. Additionally, we experienced a less favorable box mix along with modest price erosion, predominantly in our North American Industrial Packaging business. These items offset the benefit of lower planned maintenance outage expense of $0.10 as well as a lower tax rate in the quarter, which was driven by our mix of earnings as well as some one-time discrete items. 
Moving to the businesses. Results in the Industrial Packaging segment were negatively impacted by rising input costs and less favorable mix, price erosion and some operational and cost issues, all of which were more than offset -- or more than offset the benefit of lower planned maintenance outage expense. 
Relative to price and mix, IP experienced a less favorable box mix in the third quarter. Additionally, box prices were down $5 per ton due to the flow-through from the January index change, along with modest price erosion. And also worth noting, the average price for our containerboard exports was lower on average in the third quarter as prices stabilized around the exit rate from the second quarter. 
The negative impact of volume in the quarter was attributable to the seasonally lower volume in EMEA associated with our Moroccan box business. 
In operations and cost, we had a couple of isolated issues at 2 mills, which have now been resolved, and we also absorbed extra cost in the quarter due to additional overtime that we incurred in our box system to satisfy increased demand. 
Turning to Slide 9 and continuing on the theme of increased demand, our box business saw a favorable demand trend throughout the quarter with volume up 1.2% year-over-year. The increased demand was driven by favorable trends across IP's key segments highlighted on the slide. 
We continue to see robust year-over-year growth in online retail and distribution, which is a meaningful segment for our business. 
IP's customers within the processed food segment have leveled out and are showing some growth as consumer trends continue to shift to healthier product offering and our customers enhanced their offering by providing new products to satisfy these needs. 
Increased production and consumption of beef and pork are driving growth in the protein segment, and favorable weather and crop conditions have fueled strong demand in the produce segment. 
It is our view at IP that the improving box market we are seeing is not an anomaly. Even though GDP's been below expectations in 2016, the consumer segments within GDP have been some of the strongest, and at the end of the day, it's consumer activity that drives the majority of box demand. 
Turning to Consumer Packaging on Slide 10. This segment delivered another solid performance coming off a robust second quarter. Price and mix were modestly impacted by a less favorable mix of folding cup [ph] business, along with some slight erosion.  Operations performed well overall but were impacted by several minor cost items in the quarter, including FX in EMEA and other miscellaneous onetime items in the U.S. 
Moving to the Printing Papers segment, results across the global businesses were strong, partially offset by another transitional quarter for the pulp business.  Papers had a strong operational quarter, particularly in North America. Overall results for this segment were negatively impacted by a strike and other downtime we experienced in India, which unfavorably impacted results by about $5 million in the quarter. 
Relative to price and mix for North America, mix was slightly negative and pricing was flat to slightly positive. We experienced some lower prices in Europe and on our Latin American exports out of Brazil.  Overall, pulp business results declined by $15 million quarter-over-quarter, almost half of which was attributable to higher outage cost in the third quarter.  And finally, results were favorably impacted by $6 million due to FX benefits mostly in Brazil. 
Turning to Ilim. The JV delivered another strong quarter with operational EBITDA of $168 million, which translated to IP equity earnings of $46 million. Relatively stable FX throughout the quarter resulted in a slight favorable gain for the quarter. Looking ahead, the JV expects seasonally higher volume to be more than offset by seasonally higher wood cost for the fourth quarter. 
Turning to Slide 13 and moving to an update on recent financing and capital allocation actions we've taken. Early in the third quarter, we completed a debt issuance of $2.3 billion to fund our acquisition of Weyerhaeuser's pulp business as well as the voluntary pension contributions that we spoke about on our last call. Additionally, as Mark mentioned in the opening, earlier this month, IP's Board of Directors authorized an increase to the company's annual dividend of 5% to $1.85 per share, which marked the fifth consecutive annual increase to the dividend. This is another meaningful move consistent with our policy of keeping the dividend in the range of 40% to 50% of our free cash flow and speaks to our continued confidence in the sustainability of our cash generation as we look forward. 
Before I move to the outlook, let me recap how we continue to think about capital allocation. It starts with cash from operations, and we think about how we can best leverage every dollar. Beginning with capital spending, you've seen us be flexible in terms of how we think about capital: Balancing the ongoing need to maintain a world-class fleet with the realities of the marketplace and what we choose to or can afford to spend in any given year. We also continue to have a healthy pipeline of high return cost-reduction projects that we fund at an appropriate level on this basis. From there, we think about the need to utilize and maintain a strong and healthy balance sheet, with appropriate leverage and credit rating to give us financial strength and flexibility over time. This includes the need to continue to proactively manage our pension plan, as you've seen, given the various moves we've made over the last several years.  We are absolutely committed to returning a substantial portion of our cash to shareowners, as evidenced by the significant and consistent moves we've made to increase our dividend to a very meaningful level. Additionally, we supplemented this cash to shareholders with opportunistic share repurchases and we'll continue to thoughtfully utilize this option in the future. 
While we're doing all of these, we continue to look for select, value-creating investment opportunities which fit our advantaged position and advantaged markets strategy. These may come in the form of M&A like the Weyerhaeuser pulp acquisition, or could be more modest bolt-on types of opportunities like the Madrid mill, [ph] Riegelwood and our projects within North American Industrial Packaging. Bottom line, we continue to feel that a relentless focus on strong cash generation and a balanced approach to capital allocation is the right strategy for IP to create long-term value for our shareholders. 
So moving to the fourth quarter outlook. I'll cover the details around the typical seasonal impacts that we see as we move from the third to the fourth quarter, but additionally we have a couple of onetime nonrecurring items that are expected to impact results for the quarter as well. 
So starting at the top. We expect daily demand to remain strong. However, volume will be lower due to 4 less shipping days in our North American Corrugated Packaging business. This is expected to negatively impact North American packaging business results by about $50 million. We expect seasonally stronger volume in the Brazil paper's business, along with seasonal demand improvement in EMEA Packaging. 
Relative to price and mix, due to the implementation of the North American containerboard and box price increases, we expect favorable impact in the fourth quarter to be about $20 million. 
Relative to the North American pulp business, we expect unfavorable impact of about $10 million as we continue to supply additional tons of softwood market pulp into less than favorable market conditions as we work towards qualifying and supplying more fluff pulp out of the new capacity at Riegelwood. Additionally, we expect to see benefits of recently announced and implemented price increases in Brazil papers in the quarter. 
Moving to operations and other. We experienced disruptions with Hurricane Matthew in October that unfavorably affected our North American businesses where we have primary mills and significant business on the East Coast. 
In our North American papers and pulp business, this, along with other normal [ph] fourth quarter seasonal cost impacts, are expected to unfavorably impact results by $25 million. 
In our North American Industrial Packaging business, we will also see the impact of Hurricane Matthew on our results. Additionally, we expect to incur a noncash charge associated with inventory revaluation due to our LIFO accounting convention related to the North American containerboard price increase. These items are expected to unfavorably impact results by $35 million. 
So as you think about the fourth quarter, the all-in impact of the onetime items I just covered above, including Hurricane Matthew and the noncash inventory charge in North American Industrial Packaging, is roughly $45 million that will not repeat after the fourth quarter. 
Moving to input costs on top of the impact we saw on the third quarter, we expect to see additional energy cost in North America as well as inflationary pressure on inputs in our EMEA business. We expect the unfavorable impact across our North American businesses to be about $12 million and about $6 million in Europe. 
Maintenance outage expenses are expected to increase slightly by $7 million. We expect Ilim results to be slightly less favorable due to lower operational EBITDA, along with the non-repeat of the favorable $0.01 FX impact from Q3. And finally, we do expect some modest impacts from the other items, as we've noted at the bottom of the slide. 
So with -- now, let me turn it back over to Mark.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Carol. In closing, International Paper continues to deliver solid performance in a global environment that presents plenty of challenges. As Carol mentioned, we remain highly focus on cash generation and we're on track for another very strong year
componenttext:
Thanks, Carol. In closing, International Paper continues to deliver solid performance in a global environment that presents plenty of challenges. As Carol mentioned, we remain highly focus on cash generation and we're on track for another very strong year. We also remain focused on return on invested capital and are delivering another year of strong returns solidly above 10%, which is well above our cost of capital. 
As I think about where we are, how we expect to finish the year and what next year looks like, we are seeing some near-term margin squeeze across many of our businesses as some price erosion has occurred while input costs have turned up. The good news is we continue to execute well and our margins remain strong overall. We also have some upside ahead, particularly in the North American Industrial Packaging business with the price increases which are underway. In addition to that, while market fundamentals for our global pulp business may remain challenged for a while, the Weyerhaeuser pulp acquisition provides real and significant synergy opportunities that we can begin to bring to the bottom line as soon as we close the transaction. And while it's a bit further off [ph] due to the conversion, our newly acquired Madrid mill provides nice upside and earnings for our European box business. 
With our continued focus on cash generation and thoughtful approach to capital allocation, I remain confident in our ability to continue to generate meaningful value for our shareholders. 
And with that, we'll open the floor for questions.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe if you could provide a little bit more color. You were talking about another transitional quarter in the pulp business. I assume it has a lot to do with Riegelwood. Can you explain to us where you are in that process and how much in t
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe if you could provide a little bit more color. You were talking about another transitional quarter in the pulp business. I assume it has a lot to do with Riegelwood. Can you explain to us where you are in that process and how much in the way of cost you're entailing? And when you get to the other side of it, what type of opportunity exists? And I realize it gets complicated by the Weyerhaeuser acquisition also being in process. But if you can  kind of isolate the -- what you were highlighting as the transitional quarter for the pulp business?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Mark. The third quarter was the first full quarter that we had operations on the converted [ph] machine. And I would say, from our capital project planning and our ramp-up plan, we're pretty much online. And the transitional comment is reall
componenttext: Mark, this is Mark. The third quarter was the first full quarter that we had operations on the converted [ph] machine. And I would say, from our capital project planning and our ramp-up plan, we're pretty much online. And the transitional comment is really, as you know, when we think about fluff pulp, we have to qualify that with each and every customer, and that's what we're undergoing right now. So in the interim, in order to run the machine and make the fluff trials, we make regular market softwood. And obviously, pricing has been a little bit depressed. Demand is good. It's -- global softwood's [ph] up 4%, but we're selling in -- the market pulp into a lower-priced environment. So as we get our specialty pulp, fluff and other grades qualified, the mix on the asset will move up dramatically over time. And we are right on schedule with that and expect to be successful in our different customer trials.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so when you get to the other side of where you are, what type of financial impact -- if market conditions were similar to what they were in the third quarter, what type of financial upside would there be as you look at that business?
componenttext: And so when you get to the other side of where you are, what type of financial impact -- if market conditions were similar to what they were in the third quarter, what type of financial upside would there be as you look at that business?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well I don't have a quantified number right off the top of my head. But when you think about the delta between fluff and market pulp prices, and you look at that kind of margin enhancement, that's where the real benefit would come from. And as you mention
componenttext: Well I don't have a quantified number right off the top of my head. But when you think about the delta between fluff and market pulp prices, and you look at that kind of margin enhancement, that's where the real benefit would come from. And as you mentioned, Mark, it will be a little bit of a multivariable situation when we bring on our Weyerhaeuser acquisition, then a big part of the synergy opportunity is maximizing the efficiency of where we make what products. So that'll start as soon as we close the transaction and that'll put the margin improvement for making the better grades on a little bit of a turbocharger because we'll be moving grades around to the right assets.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my first question, maybe piggybacking on Debbie, teeing [ph] up the box price question. Obviously, for your own business, when we look at your business or when you look at it and you see, on the one hand, there was sufficient weakness in demand, o
componenttext: I guess my first question, maybe piggybacking on Debbie, teeing [ph] up the box price question. Obviously, for your own business, when we look at your business or when you look at it and you see, on the one hand, there was sufficient weakness in demand, or however you would categorize it, to lead to box price erosion, can you comment, perhaps provide some anecdotes or some quantification in terms of how things strengthened for you such that you're now in the process of implementing your own containerboard and box price increase? And the related question I had on that, and then I'll have one follow-on, is when we look at the scanner [ph] data, obviously, it doesn't exactly map to your corrugated business, but the trends from Consumer Packaging land have not been particularly stellar. How do you begin to reconcile that [ph] from your vantage point -- you have the biggest one in the market -- [ph] with what's been better containerboard and corrugated demand, really, over the last couple of months? And I'll -- I have one follow-on after that.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let's take the last question first, George. I think box demand -- and it can always change. It's only as good as our forecast. But box demand is playing out more or less the way we have seen it for a while now in the course of 2016. So we always saw
componenttext: Sure. Let's take the last question first, George. I think box demand -- and it can always change. It's only as good as our forecast. But box demand is playing out more or less the way we have seen it for a while now in the course of 2016. So we always saw it strengthening. Our model was predicting based on economic performance and influence that we were going to strengthen through the second half of the year, and so we're seeing that. It's a little bit better, quite frankly, than we might have thought. But our experience has been pretty good. It's evidenced by the numbers that we posted on demand growth. Back to your first question, I think there's a few things to keep in mind. First of all, we don't see the dynamics around this price increase being any -- materially different than any other price increase we've ever had. If you look at being down $5 in the quarter, I just explained a part of that is mix, but some of it was the publication down, which happened earlier in the year, and then also just normal activity. That normal activity has a lag to it, right? So some of what's showing up in the quarter is stuff that has already happened and now is just materializing. So when we communicated the price increase to our customers, we were looking at the fundamentals that we saw a point in time and then our view of how they were going to look going forward. And if anything, I'd say they turned out to be a little bit stronger than what we originally viewed.

componenttext: Yes, George. So the delta is, remember, I mentioned other seasonal increases. So the simple way to think about that is the total of 60 [ph] minus the 45, [ph] that would imply the balance of the 15 [ph] would be other normal seasonal increases from third to fourth.

componenttext: I guess a question for me and just back on the box [ph] side of things. I mean, among investors, there's obviously a lot of questions and debate whether or not how successful you're going to be able to push through the box price increase. But just curious, how much of that pricing there is contractually tied to PBW [ph]? And can you give us a sense of how much of your business is up for bid any given year as the contract roll off?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Philip, it's Tim. It varies. So much [ph] is up for bid year-to-year. We've seen some pretty dramatic swings. It's just based on length of contract, length of agreements that we have with customers and then opportunities that we see along the way for eith
componenttext: Philip, it's Tim. It varies. So much [ph] is up for bid year-to-year. We've seen some pretty dramatic swings. It's just based on length of contract, length of agreements that we have with customers and then opportunities that we see along the way for either adding to position and renegotiating early or not. So pretty much everything that we have is based on some form of either contract or customer agreement that we have, whether it's completely formal in a way of contract or it's some other type of agreement. So what we do is we go through, similar to every other price increase we've ever had, and for the number of customers we have, it comes down to customer-by-customer across the whole business.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And Tim you mentioned earlier just in terms of this implementation from what you're seeing thus far, it seems like pretty consistent move up [ph] that you've seen in the box, is that fair characterization?

componenttextpreview: Yes, I see no dynamics or circumstances that would say it's any different than what we've seen other price increases.
componenttext: Yes, I see no dynamics or circumstances that would say it's any different than what we've seen other price increases.

componenttext: It's Mike Amick. I'll characterize market is kind of okay. We're kind of heading into seasonally slower fourth quarter, but our volume quarter-over-quarter I n Consumer Packaging was about flat. The good news is that we're also seeing a little bit of an uptick in foodservice both in terms of shipments we saw on the fourth quarter as well as bookings. we're a little bit optimistic or biased a little bit in terms of what we're seeing. The in-store traffic with foodservice, which is kind of single-serve retail has been a little bit of a headwind this year as you can see, reported out the some of the retailers. But overall, we performed pretty well in that segment and continue to do so.

componenttext: Mark, this is Carol. So let me start that by saying that this year, our CapEx target is $1.3 billion. Our plans for next year, at this point, are influenced, of course, by the acquisition of the Weyerhaeuser fiber business. So including that business, our plans at this point are about $1.5 billion of CapEx. And included in that $1.3 billion and that $1.5 billion is the continuation of the implementation of the project that we spoke about in our North American Industrial Packaging business that Tim and his team are executing against.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then I just have 2 quick follow-ons  One, Tim, can you just clarify where you guys stand on containerboard export pricing? And whether you've announced anything there? And just what the volume is for you relative to your overall containerboard busin
componenttext: Okay. Then I just have 2 quick follow-ons  One, Tim, can you just clarify where you guys stand on containerboard export pricing? And whether you've announced anything there? And just what the volume is for you relative to your overall containerboard business? And then Mike, I noticed that the food service revenues were flat and I just -- I know you picked up a lot of cup contracts over the last few years and I just wonder has that all played out at this point?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's Tim. On export, price is fairly stable. As Carol mentioned on the front end, demand has been pretty good. This year, kraft linerboard exports, in total, for U.S. producers, is up about 2.5%. We look at the demand across the regions, and we say,
componenttext: Yes. It's Tim. On export, price is fairly stable. As Carol mentioned on the front end, demand has been pretty good. This year, kraft linerboard exports, in total, for U.S. producers, is up about 2.5%. We look at the demand across the regions, and we say, we kind of expect somewhere between 2% and 3.5% so it seems like it's right in the expectations may be on the low side of expectations for growth. For us, it's somewhere between 12% and 15%. It varies. But we look at it as, for our business, what we're doing is responding to what customers are demanding based on their needs. And there's been some changes in trade flows over the course of the past year given the FX volatility. But we see the market is pretty stable and continuing to go up what would be an expected rate.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, no price hikes there, right?
componenttext: Okay, no price hikes there, right?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It feels like things have firmed quite a bit. Our supply chain is very tight at the moment. We're struggling to even keep pace with the demand that we're getting from customers. So at the moment, things are extending out a little bit in terms of lead time
componenttext: It feels like things have firmed quite a bit. Our supply chain is very tight at the moment. We're struggling to even keep pace with the demand that we're getting from customers. So at the moment, things are extending out a little bit in terms of lead times on export orders.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, on your foodservice question. Tough to simplify this, it's a little more complicated. But in terms of cups, and I'll speak in terms of the bodies themselves, our overall growth is still pretty positive. So those contracts haven't played out. Our fla
componenttext: Mark, on your foodservice question. Tough to simplify this, it's a little more complicated. But in terms of cups, and I'll speak in terms of the bodies themselves, our overall growth is still pretty positive. So those contracts haven't played out. Our flat revenue is a combination of a little bit of mix that's in there as well as some a little bit of price decline over the quarter that's been relatively small. And the lid side of the business, it's a little bit down versus the body side. But overall, we're still growing the business.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Chris Manuel with Wells Fargo.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask one, I mean, perhaps this a silly question, but it's something I just don't understand. I think you referenced $35 million of a noncash charge related to inventory revaluation as box prices or as the board price flow-through. Can you help ex
componenttext: Wanted to ask one, I mean, perhaps this a silly question, but it's something I just don't understand. I think you referenced $35 million of a noncash charge related to inventory revaluation as box prices or as the board price flow-through. Can you help explain what it is, how that works. I guess, intuitively I have been thinking the other way around that prices are obit higher.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris, this is Carol, and I'm going to attempt this to do without laboring this call with an accounting lesson, but it's somewhat of a complicated issue. In simple terms, we run our businesses in a FIFO model, first and first-out, but we keep our cor
componenttext: Yes, Chris, this is Carol, and I'm going to attempt this to do without laboring this call with an accounting lesson, but it's somewhat of a complicated issue. In simple terms, we run our businesses in a FIFO model, first and first-out, but we keep our corporate book model on a LIFO model, last in, first-out. And so we keep that you call it your LIFO reserve, your LIFO balance we just your contra in the inventor account on the corporate book. And basically you do LIFO because cost go up through time and that's the best way, the best effect to get the outcome for the company. When you have a dramatic shift and for us it's around inventory between our mills and our box plants, we charge our box plants market price so we're going to move that board into our box business at the higher price. But you do last-in, first-out relative to your accounting, so you have the balance that LIFO account. The other thing that comes into play to get that LIFO account balanced by year end. So the timing of this increase coming right at the end of the year calls us to have to balance that account in the quarter. What's most important is noncash. And in LIFO, when you make adjustments to those LIFO balance is noncash. But due to the way we run our business and our accounting convention, that charge hits us in this fourth quarter. So that's my best explanation, and we can always follow-up with more if you feel like you want some more information.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's helpful. So it's not just what would have been referenced here. It's accumulative catch-up for the full year as well.
componenttext: No, I think that's helpful. So it's not just what would have been referenced here. It's accumulative catch-up for the full year as well.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You got to get that -- what you do is you get that LIFO has to balance by year-end. So if this happened earlier in the year, we would have done it through the period of time. Why it's kind of the unique, significant size and of course, the scale of our bu
componenttext: You got to get that -- what you do is you get that LIFO has to balance by year-end. So if this happened earlier in the year, we would have done it through the period of time. Why it's kind of the unique, significant size and of course, the scale of our business mix makes it significant in the size and scale.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Follow-up question I had was for Tim. So you kind of referenced that box demand has been playing out, I think in response to George's question earlier, that box demand has been playing out kind of as you've anticipated. and It's pretty sol
componenttext: That's helpful. Follow-up question I had was for Tim. So you kind of referenced that box demand has been playing out, I think in response to George's question earlier, that box demand has been playing out kind of as you've anticipated. and It's pretty solid here to the back half of the year. As you look forward and again, fully appreciating this is a very fluid and dynamic market and model probably, how are you feeling regarding the next, let's call it, 12 to 18 months, I mean, do you still feel that box demand can continue at 1 point, 1.5 point sort of pace? What do you think the puts and takes are there?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, 18 months is a little bit beyond my radar screen there. So I'd put it this way, in the moment looking forward over the next couple of quarters we, feel pretty good. Our models is only as good as what people are saying the next couple of quarters are
componenttext: Yes, 18 months is a little bit beyond my radar screen there. So I'd put it this way, in the moment looking forward over the next couple of quarters we, feel pretty good. Our models is only as good as what people are saying the next couple of quarters are going to be on any number of economic activity levels. And so it's been kind of in the zone where there hasn't been all a whole load of change to that it does affect the components of the model. So I feel good about the fourth quarter, seeing nothing that should make us feel anyway but positive as we go into the first quarter of next year.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Scott Gaffner with Barclays.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Scott Gaffner with Barclays.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to talk about North American Industrial Packaging for a minute. And obviously the volumes are coming in relatively strong. And you mentioned some of the infant cost inflation, but I guess, as I look at the year-over-year EBITDA bridge, the inp
componenttext: Just wanted to talk about North American Industrial Packaging for a minute. And obviously the volumes are coming in relatively strong. And you mentioned some of the infant cost inflation, but I guess, as I look at the year-over-year EBITDA bridge, the input costs are relatively flat year-over-year. So just trying to reconcile, I mean, when we look at the increases, and you mentioned a lot of tightness in your export market, is it more of a supply demand-driven price increase relative to an input costs increase?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think all of those factors weigh on price movement. I would just say this in terms of year-over-year on input costs, some of it is timing. And input started moving up during the third quarter. And the other piece of this, inputs, no question, have been
componenttext: I think all of those factors weigh on price movement. I would just say this in terms of year-over-year on input costs, some of it is timing. And input started moving up during the third quarter. And the other piece of this, inputs, no question, have been a tailwind for the past 12 or 18 months, but that's recently changed. And I think what may not be as obvious to people looking at our results is the tailwind from input costs did a great job helping us cover normal inflation that we encounter year in and year out. And all of a sudden, that tailwinds has turned into a headwind and so the inflation is there and know the input costs prices are there, and you kind of a double impact.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just sticking there for a minute. I think Carol maybe mentioned normal competitive box pressure at least in the third quarter. When I go back and look at the last 2 price increases and 2012 and 2013, I think, there was a period of time there wer
componenttext: Okay. And just sticking there for a minute. I think Carol maybe mentioned normal competitive box pressure at least in the third quarter. When I go back and look at the last 2 price increases and 2012 and 2013, I think, there was a period of time there were it felt like be competitive dynamic in the box business had slowed down a little bit. You're actually able to hold pricing on the box side. It did something changed over the last 12 months maybe the box business came a little bit more competitive just versus post price increase environment?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think so. I think what you got to keep in mind is in January, I mean it's always a competitive business but in January, there's a published down that impacted price, and it's been working its way through our financials based on all of the diff
componenttext: No, I don't think so. I think what you got to keep in mind is in January, I mean it's always a competitive business but in January, there's a published down that impacted price, and it's been working its way through our financials based on all of the different customer contracts and agreements that we have. And so, if there's a change this year over prior periods, it's -- that happened to us early in the year and we've been dealing with it.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And last one for me. In the prepared to slide, Slide 9, you mentioned retail and traditional distribution growth. I think you said, it was a meaningful segment for you now. Were you referring to e-commerce? And if so, how big is e-commerce now for t
componenttext: Okay. And last one for me. In the prepared to slide, Slide 9, you mentioned retail and traditional distribution growth. I think you said, it was a meaningful segment for you now. Were you referring to e-commerce? And if so, how big is e-commerce now for the total company?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, on a relative basis, it's still -- it's big but on relative basis, to still more but growing at a rapid rate. And it's such as online retail, it's also traditional distribution. We have exposure across the spectrum, and it's been performing very wel
componenttext: Well, on a relative basis, it's still -- it's big but on relative basis, to still more but growing at a rapid rate. And it's such as online retail, it's also traditional distribution. We have exposure across the spectrum, and it's been performing very well for us. So that's one part. The other positive is that a protein segment for us, which has been under some pressure over the past couple of years since like it is coming back in a more stable way. And processed wood for us has also been good. So I think it's a mix of different segments.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question has to do with something that's kind of perplexes us a little bit and that is if you -- we have done a deep dive into the sort of unaccounted for tonnage which averages somewhere of 100,000 to 200,000 tons a month when you get the monthly d
componenttext: First question has to do with something that's kind of perplexes us a little bit and that is if you -- we have done a deep dive into the sort of unaccounted for tonnage which averages somewhere of 100,000 to 200,000 tons a month when you get the monthly data and it seems to suggest that there's a rather sharp roughly 200,000 ton drop in what would consider in-transit inventories in the last 2 months. And, I guess, if that's true, that would show up in your system with, I guess, lengthening delivery times, if that's in fact true. Are you seeing anything in your business that would suggest that there are less out in the field, I'm talking about trucks and railcars, and that's affecting your business at all?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think what we've experienced during the course of the year and it started late last year was the supply chain working very efficiently and effectively and so things are flowing through fairly well. And another piece of it that can impact it is just
componenttext: Yes, I think what we've experienced during the course of the year and it started late last year was the supply chain working very efficiently and effectively and so things are flowing through fairly well. And another piece of it that can impact it is just how months end in terms of whether they end on a weekend or not and technically, things have to be unloaded and hit the floor to be not in-transit any more. So there's some anomalies month-to-month and just in terms of how the month ends. But our supply chain right now is incredibly tight. So we're -- as I mentioned earlier on exports, we're pushing things out, and we're just trying to catch up to what we think would be more sustainable levels as infantry across our system.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just getting back on the numbers to make sure I understood them. componenttext: So Chip, the $25 million that we referenced was for paper and pulp and some subsegment of that was Matthew, so there's some other cost there. componenttext: Okay. headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you've definitely -- that's the right direction, for sure.
componenttext: I think you've definitely -- that's the right direction, for sure.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last one real quickly. I noticed in the data the last 2 months that, while the [indiscernible] gives us their survey every year roughly in May, they certainly imply a certain capacity when you divide what they say production is into the ope
componenttext: Okay. And then last one real quickly. I noticed in the data the last 2 months that, while the [indiscernible] gives us their survey every year roughly in May, they certainly imply a certain capacity when you divide what they say production is into the operating rate. It looks like capacity is actually down the last couple of months. And I didn't know if there's anything you're seeing out there that might explain why we just literally don't see any projects financed across the industry to add discrete capacity addition, especially given the fact that demand is growing especially in tons?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chip, this is Mark. I think the capacity evolution in containerboard, you go back a couple of years with some of the additions that has come on, there's been a mixed track record and the success in bringing that board into the natural backs, peoples inves
componenttext: Chip, this is Mark. I think the capacity evolution in containerboard, you go back a couple of years with some of the additions that has come on, there's been a mixed track record and the success in bringing that board into the natural backs, peoples investment decision. I think the markets pretty well-balanced. And I think that that's really the reality. You've got more than just containerboard, you got to figure out the way to get it through to supply chain into a package that's design for a customer. So downstream, converting in the value chain, all of those things are important. And so I think, right now, we said this 2 years ago and 18 months ago that we thought capacity would play out, be absorbed, some would work, som wouldn't and I think that's where we are.

componenttext: I just want to ask about the containerboard economic downtime. It picked up a little bit from the second quarter and I presume of that this just to help support a price increase you have out there in the market. Now that have you've got the $40 through, just wondering presumably margins are going to be better going forward, just wondering if we could see that tick back down to some of the levels that we saw before 2016, 2015?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the premise of the question is not on target. We run our system based on how we need to optimize our margins and service some of our facilities. And so tons are not tons, the mills produced a range of products. We need more of some and less o
componenttext: Yes, I think the premise of the question is not on target. We run our system based on how we need to optimize our margins and service some of our facilities. And so tons are not tons, the mills produced a range of products. We need more of some and less of others. And we balance it out, to make sure that we're doing that thing from a cash standpoint and the right thing from a margin standpoint.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay, got it. And just wanted to better understand the timing of the earnings benefit you'd expect from the higher containerboard pricing. I think you referenced a $20 million benefit into 4Q. So obviously, less than the annualized impact of it. But do you think it will be kind of fully in your numbers by the end of the first quarter and so you'd kind of a see it in the 2Q numbers? Or how do you kind of expect it to flow-through the number?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I expect it to flow-through pretty much on the same pace and tract that prior increases have flowed through. So we've got tens of thousands of customers, we've got contracts and agreements with all of them and then follow the cadence of those agreements.
componenttext: I expect it to flow-through pretty much on the same pace and tract that prior increases have flowed through. So we've got tens of thousands of customers, we've got contracts and agreements with all of them and then follow the cadence of those agreements. And it's really no different than what it's been in prior times. It's usually pretty fast. It's usually over a couple of quarters.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that helps. And just my last one if I could, I think looks like at the maintenance schedule it looks it came to on down a little for industrial and Printing Papers. Just wondering if there's some stuff that's just kind of slipping to 2017? Or are yo
componenttext: Okay, that helps. And just my last one if I could, I think looks like at the maintenance schedule it looks it came to on down a little for industrial and Printing Papers. Just wondering if there's some stuff that's just kind of slipping to 2017? Or are you just seeing better productivity or may be lower cost? Or just what kinds of driving that?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Carol. One of the things that we do is we put a plan together at the beginning of the year of what we feel like where we want to execute against and then we work like crazy throughout the year to find better ways to do things and opportunit
componenttext: Brian, this is Carol. One of the things that we do is we put a plan together at the beginning of the year of what we feel like where we want to execute against and then we work like crazy throughout the year to find better ways to do things and opportunities. And so evidenced, by the way, Mark talked about the business and the conditions, we've worked hard to find better ways and yes, something we pushed out, but we feel very comfortable with those decisions, and we thought we've got a great plan and a good plan for the fourth quarter.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson with KeyBanc.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The one on -- just follow-up on box demand. I know George asked earlier about the apparent disconnect between CPG demand and box demand, but there's also be a disconnect between industrial demand and box demand. So industrial and CPG are 2 pretty big piec
componenttext: The one on -- just follow-up on box demand. I know George asked earlier about the apparent disconnect between CPG demand and box demand, but there's also be a disconnect between industrial demand and box demand. So industrial and CPG are 2 pretty big pieces of the box market that seemed to be flat going in the wrong direction. So what are we missing in terms of the why box demand is doing apparently much better than the broader economy?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that I can answer that fully, but I would say this. We think there's nondurable production is in part a good proxy for box demand, but it's not always in the moment lined up exactly the same way. There's been period where box demand is outper
componenttext: I don't know that I can answer that fully, but I would say this. We think there's nondurable production is in part a good proxy for box demand, but it's not always in the moment lined up exactly the same way. There's been period where box demand is outperformed nondurables and vice versa. And there's other components of economic activity that actually influenced box demand. Some of our demand trends have been the things I mentioned earlier where [indiscernible] approaching starting to come back of some depressed levels for the past couple of years. Distribution and online retail continues to grow for us quite well. And process would is actually been pretty good for us. You have to remember a year or so ago, the shrinking at 3% doesn't feel like it's doing that anymore. So it's not stellar growth, but it's not performing as bad as it has in prior periods. So I think that based on the way we look at how box demand gets driven, it's performing the way we would expect it to in the moment.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: At then, it's Mark. Just to kind of -- one of the views we have in addition to the segment discussion Tim has, if you think back to the GDP number for the quarter, and you look at the total, it was very modest. But if you look at the components, the consu
componenttext: At then, it's Mark. Just to kind of -- one of the views we have in addition to the segment discussion Tim has, if you think back to the GDP number for the quarter, and you look at the total, it was very modest. But if you look at the components, the consumer section of GDP was up almost 3%. Those are the kinds of activity by the consumer that drive box demand. Even if they're trading out of the consumer good into a fresh good or other segments, with a consumer component of GDP at 2.8%, it's pretty squared with our mind why box demand is at a 1.5%. There's a lot of negatives on the non-consumer side, which netted out to 1.4% GDP. So for us, it looks like it squares up pretty well.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the clarification. Tim or Mark, just one more. I think, Tim you talked about your supply chain being quite high, I think in response to George's question about box price erosion. You're talking about some of it has a lagged from the January som
componenttext: Thanks for the clarification. Tim or Mark, just one more. I think, Tim you talked about your supply chain being quite high, I think in response to George's question about box price erosion. You're talking about some of it has a lagged from the January some of it is related to competitive activity. So if your supply chain is really tight, why would there be sufficient competitive activity on the box side such that you're seeing erosion in your box prices to a fairly meaningful degree?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and mix was a piece of it too, Adam. And I think just timing. Some of these things that settled as a negotiating point at a time work their way towards implementation. And so, I mean, to me, we're not seeing anything unusual or abnormal from every ot
componenttext: Yes, and mix was a piece of it too, Adam. And I think just timing. Some of these things that settled as a negotiating point at a time work their way towards implementation. And so, I mean, to me, we're not seeing anything unusual or abnormal from every other time we had inflections in pricing. So it feels completely normal to me.

componenttext: No. What that was is we were looking at potential containerboard investments in India in order to do that, we have to make some investments to secure some potential land for sites. And then we just did some engineering work to model different types of it business models, whether it be a recycled machine or whether it included box business are not. So those engineering charges we didn't build anything, we just did some engineering and then we had the small security deposit on some land.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a wrinkle please on the LIFO, FIFO question, and Carol, confirm what we know, which is you're doing transfer pricing at market value. So I guess I just wanted to know is it fair to say that the delta in November will remain $50 a ton o
componenttext: Okay. And then just a wrinkle please on the LIFO, FIFO question, and Carol, confirm what we know, which is you're doing transfer pricing at market value. So I guess I just wanted to know is it fair to say that the delta in November will remain $50 a ton or is the PPW print cut that to $40?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: Steve, I appreciate the question, but I would respectfully decline to answer as the exact transfer pricing in our company. But what, I would say, and I'm looking at my colleague Tim and Bill across the table, we announced a $50 increase for October with our customers, and that's the increase that were out pushing and implementing at this point in time.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari with Citi.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari with Citi.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on Printing Papers. In the quarter, I think you referenced the lower prices in Europe and some of your Brazilian exports. I'm just wondering, has that continued in 4Q? And with paper prices may be improving domestically in Brazil, are ther
componenttext: Just a question on Printing Papers. In the quarter, I think you referenced the lower prices in Europe and some of your Brazilian exports. I'm just wondering, has that continued in 4Q? And with paper prices may be improving domestically in Brazil, are there opportunities to repatriate some of those export tons to Brazil if demand is a little better there?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anthony, this is Mike. On Brazil, the majority what showed up in pricing for export was actually mix of product and geographic mix. So in terms of the price same store, if you will, or same markets, pretty stable.
componenttext: Anthony, this is Mike. On Brazil, the majority what showed up in pricing for export was actually mix of product and geographic mix. So in terms of the price same store, if you will, or same markets, pretty stable.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. And then just kind of attacking on a general question on Brazil. The 4Q view, I mean you get a little bit of help from seasonality but are using any kind of improvement or infections in Brazilian demand either paper or containerboard just from
componenttext: Okay, okay. And then just kind of attacking on a general question on Brazil. The 4Q view, I mean you get a little bit of help from seasonality but are using any kind of improvement or infections in Brazilian demand either paper or containerboard just from may be a bit more stronger demand there or kind of recovering economy at all?

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are. We are seeing some improved demand in our box business and for our box business, has one of the best quarter since we've owned it in Brazil. And so as the government moves to a more stable situation, I think there's many experts saying that could
componenttext: We are. We are seeing some improved demand in our box business and for our box business, has one of the best quarter since we've owned it in Brazil. And so as the government moves to a more stable situation, I think there's many experts saying that could turn positive in the economy next year, which will be helpful. And on the paper side, demand in Brazil is pretty steady. It's not as high as it was pre-recession and pre-crisis. But pretty steady and as a follow-up on the question you asked about export, because the Brazil demand is steady, we have announced a price increase for the export business, that's effective in the fourth quarter. So that whole system of Brazilian production for Brazil and then the Brazilian production for the rest of Latin America and the Middle East, and Africa, and Europe is all seems to be getting a bit stronger, so we are out with the price increase for the fourth quarter in the export business.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016

componenttext: And your final question comes from the line of Gail Glazerman with Wells equity research.

headline: International Paper Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Gail. This is Carol. So just one change to what you said. We actually had to revalue the pension at the end of the third quarter. Once we triggered the accounting treatment in the second quarter, that put you kind of in our new territory and if you h
componenttext: Yes, Gail. This is Carol. So just one change to what you said. We actually had to revalue the pension at the end of the third quarter. Once we triggered the accounting treatment in the second quarter, that put you kind of in our new territory and if you have any change in the pension, you're required to remeasure. So we actually remeasured in the third quarter. And in the third quarter remeasurement, the interest rates discount rate, they dropped another 20 basis points. So what you're seeing for that, the gap, the you're seeing positive impact of the contribution and the performance, negative impact from the discount rate, and that will all be very clear to you when we come out with our Q.
